Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ year old female who presented for revision 
rhytidectomy, bilateral upper blepharoplasties, chin nevus 
excision, on ___. She tolerated the surgery well and had 
no events overnight postoperatively. Her incisions were clean, 
dry, and intact. Her pain was controlled, and she had no other 
concerning symptoms. She voided spontaneously and tolerated a 
regular diet. Her vital signs were stable, written instructions 
were provided, and she was appropriate for discharge.

1.  Acetaminophen 650 mg PO TID  
2.  Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID

hours Disp #*10 Tablet Refills:*1 
4.  OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) 5 mg PO Q4H:PRN Pain - 
Moderate  
5.  amLODIPine 5 mg PO DAILY

Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Facial skin laxity

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Discharge Instructions:
* Please contact Dr. ___ any serious change in your 
symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern you.
* Please resume all regular home medications and take any new 
meds as ordered.
* Do not drive or operate heavy machinery while taking any 
narcotic pain medication. You may have constipation when taking 
narcotic pain medications (oxycodone, percocet, vicodin, 
hydrocodone, dilaudid, etc.); you should continue drinking 
fluids, you may take stool softeners, and should eat foods that 
are high in fiber.
.
You may take a bath or shower, but do not get your incisions wet 
until instructed by Dr. ___.
* Keep your dressings in place until your follow up appointment 
with Dr. ___
* No strenuous activity until instructed by Dr. ___.
* Finish all of your antibiotics
* Please call Dr. ___ if you have any acute 
swelling in your neck or face
* Please report any eye drainage or acute swelling or vision 
changes to Dr. ___.
* ___ continue cold compresses to eyes for comfort
* Sleep with head elevated to help with swelling
* do not take any medicines such as Motrin, Aspirin, Advil or 
Ibuprofen etc
.
Return to the ER if:
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your 
medications.
* If you have shaking chills, fever greater than 101.5 (F) 
degrees or 38 (C) degrees, increased redness, swelling or 
discharge from incision, chest pain, shortness of breath, or 
anything else that is troubling you.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

___ w/ PMH sig for alcoholism and HTN who is transferred from

strike. Pt was walking down steps at her home when she fell 
yesterday morning. She had 1 bottle of wine to drink before 
falling but she does not recall feeling intoxicated. She does 
not remember the fall and denies having felt lightheaded. She 
remembers waking up on the ground and activating her lifeline. 
There was bloody discharge from her R ear. She also bit her 
tongue when she fell.

Pt reports that she drinks 1 bottle of wine every day.  She 
cannot recall the last time she did not drink a bottle of wine. 
She has had many falls, on average ___ times per month.  All of 
them occur just as this one did.

She was brought by ambulance to the OSH ED where a CT scan 
revealed a R temporal bone fracture and SAH w/ blood in the 
sylvian fissure. Pt was transferred to ___ where she was 
evaluated in the ED.  Vitals in the ED were T 98.4, HR 99, BP

dose of 500 mg. She was also given Baclofen 10 mg and Tylenol 
___ mg. Repeat head CT showed no progression of bleeding. Pt was

admitted to medicine.

ADMISSION IMAGING:
___ ___:
1. Stable focus of subarachnoid blood within the right sylvian 
fissure underlying a fracture of the right temporal bone. No new 
foci of intracranial hemorrhage identified. 
2.  Fracture of the right temporal bone extends from the 
squamous portion, into the mastoid portion and ends in the 
petrous portion of the temporal bone at the level of the 
ossicles. Fluid is seen within the right mastoid air cells and 
right middle ear cavity. 
3.  Stable scalp hematoma overlying the right temporal bone 
fracture.  Small scalp hematoma over the left parietal bone.

DISCHARGE LABS:
___ 07:35AM BLOOD Glucose-96 UreaN-19 Creat-0.8 Na-131* 
K-4.0 Cl-95* HCO3-25 AnGap-___ w/ PMH sig for alcoholism and HTN who is transferred from 
OSH w/ R temporal bone fracture and SAH after fall w/ head 
strike.

ACTIVE ISSUES:
# SAH: CT scan of head showed stable right sylvian fissure 
bleeding in setting of fall. Pt evaluated by neurosurgery in ED 
who felt that operative management was not necessary. 
Recommended 500 mg Keppra BID x10 days for seizure prophylaxis. 
C-spine cleared clinically.

# R temporal bone fracture: Pt evaluated by ENT in ED. If facial 
nerve weakness develops, pt may benefit from treatment with 
steroids per ENT. Pt placed on CSF leak precautions: HOB 
elevation, standing stool softeners, sneeze with mouth open, no 
nose blowing. Also placed on ciprofloxacin and dexamethasone 
otic drops. Pt discharged on ofloxacin 0.3% otic drops per ENT 
team. Pt should keep ear dry until follow up (cotton ball in 
ear, then vaseline smeared over ear and cotton when washing 
hair). Pt should have audiogram in 1 wk and f/u with ENT in ___ 
wks. Instructions given on how to follow up.

# Syncope: Most likely ___ to intoxication and possibly volume 
depletion (hyponatremic and BUN:Cr ratio >20). Alcohol level 150 
on admission. Received 1 L NS first night of admission. Feels 
steady on feet, not light-headed. EKG w/o arrythmia, ischemia. 
No events on telemetry.

# HTN: Home antihypertensives (HCTZ, lisinopril, and metoprolol) 
administered. BP fell from 150s systolic to 100s. Pt not 
symptomatic with this. She is not currently seen by a primary 
care provider but gets prescriptions refilled for these meds. Pt 
instructed to discontinue these meds and see a primary care 
doctor to check her BP within 1 wk.

# Alcohol abuse: Pt on CIWA scale. No benzodiazepines 
administered. Pt declines detox at this time. She was counseled 
about the dangers of heavy alcohol use and instructed to seek 
professional help to remain sober.

CHRONIC ISSUES:
#Depression: Stable. Continued on fluoxetine 80 mg QD.

#Insomnia: Stable. Continued on trazodone 100 mg QHS.

#Hypothyroidism: Stable. Continued on levothyroxine 125 mcg QD.

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
-- Pt will need audiogram in 1 wk and ENT f/u for temporal bone 
fracture in ___ wks
-- Pt will need to see a primary care doctor in 1 wk to check 
her BP
-- Sobriety will be an ongoing issue for her.  She understands 
the risks of drinking and will discuss with her new PCP.

Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
PRIMARY DIAGNOSES
Subarachnoid hemorrhage
Temporal bone fracture
Syncope

SECONDARY DIAGNOSES
Alcoholism

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were hospitalized because you had a fall with a fracture of 
your skull and some bleeding around your brain. You were seen by 
the neurosurgeons who did not feel that you needed surgery but 
recommended that you take Keppra for 10 days to prevent 
seizures. You were also seen by the ENT doctors who recommended 
that you take the following precautions to prevent a leak of the 
fluid around your brain: keeping the head of your bed elevated, 
taking stool softeners, sneezing with your mouth open, and not 
blowing your nose. They also recommended that you use ofloxacin 
0.3% drops in your ears to prevent an infection. You should keep 
your ear canal dry by placing a cotton ball in the ear canal and 
putting vaseline on the outside of the cotton ball and ear canal 
when you wash your hair. 

On your last day in the hospital, your blood pressures was low 
so we cut back your blood pressure medications.  Please stop 
taking these medications until you are evaluated by the 
prescribing doctor or another healthcare provider.

As you know, drinking alcohol in large quantities is detrimental 
for your health and may lead to death.  We recommend that you 
refrain from drinking and seek professional care to remain 
sober, as abstinence is essential to avoid further injury and 
detriment (including death) from alcohol.

Finally, if you should have any signs or symptoms of alcohol 
withdrawal (tremors, confusion, hallucinations), be sure to go 
directly to a local emergency room.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

were no signs of symptoms of infection, and his gram stain of 
the fluid was negative.

surgeon felt they could not handle the problem they should call

keep left leg elevated.  Please report increased pain left leg 
and numbness of toes.

Please call your doctor or return to the emergency room if you 
have any of the following:
 

 * You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
 tightness.
 
* New or worsening cough or wheezing.
 
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your 
 medications.
 
* You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, 
 diarrhea or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry

* You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
 bowel movement.
 

* You have shaking chills, or a fever greater than 101.5 (F) 
 degrees or 38(C) degrees.
 
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that 
 concern you. 
 
* Please resume all regular home medications and take any new 
meds 
 as ordered.

evidence of MI. She had no further episodes of chest pain and 
had a cardiac stress test prior to discharge which showed normal 
myocardial perfusion and excellent exercise tolerance.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ with a recent hx of cholecystitis and cholangitis (___), 
managed medically due to concurrent NSTEMI w/trop >84 underwent 
an interval laparoscopic converted to open cholecystectomy on 
___, which was complicated by an iatrogenic CBD transection and 
cardiac enzyme elevation. The patient was transfered to ___ 
for further cardiac evaluation and management of his bile duct 
injury. Cardiology assessment recommended an alternative Toprol 
dose but otherwise recommended no further cardiac opitimization 
for surgery. The patient underwent a A PTC drain had been placed 
on ___ after occlusion was noted on ERCP at an OSH.

for monitoring on ___. There the patient was started on

pain control and was made NPO. Cardiac enzymes were cycled which 
revealed no rising troponin levels. On ___ the Pip-Tazo were 
d/c'ed and Ampicilin Sulbactam was started. The patient was then 
transferred to the floor.

with IV versions of both being disconitnued. The patient's PTBD 
drain was found to be out by the nurse in the afternoon for 
which an interventional radiology team was called for the PTBD 
drain to be replaced. After the replacement of the drain the 
patient returned to the floor in stable condition. At this time 
the patient was continued on the Vanc and the Amp-Sulbactam. 

On ___ the patient underwent preoperative evaluation.

successfully. The patient returned to the floor with an NGT, a 
PTBD, and a bulb drain to suction. After a brief, uneventful 
stay in the PACU, the patient arrived on the floor NPO, on IV 
fluids and antibiotics, with a foley catheter, and a dilaudid 
PCA for pain control. The patient was hemodynamically stable.

adequate pain control. When tolerating oral intake, the patient 
was transitioned to oral pain medications.

standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored.

Pulmonary: The patient remained stable from a pulmonary 
standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. Good pulmonary 
toilet, early ambulation and incentive spirometry were 
encouraged throughout hospitalization.

GI/GU/FEN: Post-operatively, the patient was made NPO with IV 
fluids. Diet was advanced when appropriate, which was well 
tolerated. Patient's intake and output were closely monitored, 
and IV fluid was adjusted when necessary. Electrolytes were 
routinely followed, and repleted when necessary. The patient was 
started on all home prostate medications prior to removal of 
foley. The folwy was removed and pateint voided prior to 
discharge. 

ID: The patient's white blood count and fever curves were 
closely watched for signs of infection. The patient's wound was 
monitored for possible signs of infection.

Endocrine: The patient's blood sugar was monitored throughout 
his stay; insulin dosing was adjusted accordingly.

Hematology: The patient's complete blood count was examined 
routinely. 

Prophylaxis: The patient received subcutaneous heparin and 
venodyne boots were used during this stay. He was encouraged to 
get up and ambulate as early as possible.

On ___ a repeat tube cholangiogram was obtained which 
demonstrated patent anastamosis.

At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
with stable vital signs. The patient was tolerating a regular 
diet, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled. The patient received discharge teaching and 
follow-up instructions with understanding verbalized and 
agreement with the discharge plan.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ male patient that initially presented to the 
hospital on ___ with abdominal pain and nausea.  While in 
the ED on an ultrasound and a CT scan of the abdomen were done 
and he was found to have gallstone pancreatitis.  The following 
day he was admitted to the hospital and he underwent an ERCP 
with sphincterotomy and extraction of sludge.  Surgery was 
consulted on the ___ for a possible cholecystectomy.  On 
___ he underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy after he is 
LFTs and T bili were within normal limits.  Please see operative 
report for further details on the surgery.  After an 
uncomplicated procedure he was sent to the floor and and kept 
n.p.o. given his history of severe pancreatitis.  On postop day 
3 he was found to have continuous abdominal pain it was decided 
to do CT scan of his abdomen and pelvis which showed edema and 
possible fluid surrounding the pancreas.  Given the initial 
presentation of severe pancreatitis and that in mature 
collection seen on the CT scan, it was decided not to place a 
drain in the collection and manage conservatively with 
observation.  On postop day 4 he was started on a clear liquid 
diet.  After he was tolerating clear liquid diet he was advanced 
to a regular diet.  Today he is tolerating a regular diet, has 
vital signs within normal limits, has normal bowel function, and 
reports having no abdominal pain.  He is discharged in good 
condition.

Discharge Diagnosis:
___ Pancreatitis

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS

Dear ___,

You were admitted to ___ for 
___ hepatitis and underwent an ERCP and a laparoscopic 
cholecystectomy. You are recovering well and are now ready for 
discharge. Please follow the instructions below to continue your 
recovery:

Do not drink any alcohol.  (Very important)
Please continue nutrition with Carnation breakfast with every 
meal.

Please follow up in the Acute Care Surgery clinic at the 
appointment listed below.
 
ACTIVITY:
 
o Do not drive until you have stopped taking pain medicine and 
feel you could respond in an emergency.
o You may climb stairs. 
o  You may go outside, but avoid traveling long distances until 
you see your surgeon at your next visit.
o  Don't lift more than ___ lbs for 4 weeks. (This is about 
the weight of a briefcase or a bag of groceries.) This applies 
to lifting children, but they may sit on your lap.
o You may start some light exercise when you feel comfortable.
o You will need to stay out of bathtubs or swimming pools for a 
time while your incision is healing. Ask your doctor when you 
can resume tub baths or swimming.
 
HOW YOU MAY FEEL: 
o  You may feel weak or "washed out" for a couple of weeks. You 
might want to nap often. Simple tasks may exhaust you.
o  You may have a sore throat because of a tube that was in your 
throat during surgery.
o  You might have trouble concentrating or difficulty sleeping. 
You might feel somewhat depressed.
o  You could have a poor appetite for a while. Food may seem 
unappealing.
o  All of these feelings and reactions are normal and should go 
away in a short time.  If they do not, tell your surgeon.
 
YOUR INCISION:
o You may shower. You have small plastic bandages called 
steri-strips. Do not remove steri-strips for 2 weeks. (These are 
the thin paper strips that might be on your incision.) But if 
they fall off before that that's okay).
o Your incisions may be slightly red around the stitches. This 
is normal.
o You may gently wash away dried material around your incision.
o Avoid direct sun exposure to the incision area.
o Do not use any ointments on the incision unless you were told 
otherwise.
o You may see a small amount of clear or light red fluid 
staining your dressing or clothes. If the staining is severe, 
please call your surgeon.
o You may shower. As noted above, ask your doctor when you may 
resume tub baths or swimming.
 
YOUR BOWELS:
o Constipation is a common side effect of narcotic pain 
medications. If needed, you may take a stool softener (such as 
Colace, one capsule) or gentle laxative (such as milk of 
magnesia, 1 tbs) twice a day. You can get both of these 
medicines without a prescription.
o If you go 48 hours without a bowel movement, or have pain 
moving the bowels, call your surgeon. 
 
PAIN MANAGEMENT:
o It is normal to feel some discomfort/pain following abdominal 
surgery. This pain is often described as "soreness". 
o Your pain should get better day by day. If you find the pain 
is getting worse instead of better, please contact your surgeon.
o You will receive a prescription for pain medicine to take by 
mouth. It is important to take this medicine as directed. o Do 
not take it more frequently than prescribed. Do not take more 
medicine at one time than prescribed.
o Your pain medicine will work better if you take it before your 
pain gets too severe.
o Talk with your surgeon about how long you will need to take 
prescription pain medicine. Please don't take any other pain 
medicine, including non-prescription pain medicine, unless your 
surgeon has said its okay.
o If you are experiencing no pain, it is okay to skip a dose of 
pain medicine.
o Remember to use your "cough pillow" for splinting when you 
cough or when you are doing your deep breathing exercises.
If you experience any of the following, please contact your 
surgeon:
- sharp pain or any severe pain that lasts several hours
- pain that is getting worse over time
- pain accompanied by fever of more than 101
- a drastic change in nature or quality of your pain
 
MEDICATIONS:
Take all the medicines you were on before the operation just as 
you did before, unless you have been told differently.
If you have any questions about what medicine to take or not to 
take, please call your surgeon.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
On ___, Ms. ___ was admitted to the gynecology service after 
being seen in the Emergency Department for a Bartholin's 
abscess. She was taken to the operating room on hospital day 1 
for a Batholin's marsupialization and biopsy of cyst base for a 
recurrent Bartholin's abscess with overlying cellulitis and 
failed conservative management. 
.
Initially on presenting to hospital, patient was febrile with a 
Tmax of 101.6. She was initiated on IV clindamycin and IV 
vancomycin for 24 hours afebrile. After, she was transitioned to 
a 14 day course of oral augmentin and remained afebrile during 
hospital stay.
.
Her post-operative course was uncomplicated. Immediately 
post-op, her pain was controlled with oral ibuprofen and 
acetaminophen around the clock with oral or IV dilaudid for 
breakthrough pain. Her vaginal packing and surgical were removed 
on post-operative day 1. Her diet was advanced without 
difficulty and she was able to tolerate a regular diet. She was 
able to void spontaneously the entire hospital stay.
. 
By post-operative day 1, she was tolerating a regular diet, 
voiding spontaneously, ambulating independently, and pain was 
controlled with oral medications. She was then discharged home 
on oral antibiotics in stable condition with outpatient 
follow-up scheduled.

Tylenol

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You were admitted to the gynecology service with a left 
Bartholin's gland abscess. You underwent surgical 
marsupialization. You have recovered well and the team believes 
you are ready to be discharged home on oral antibiotics. Please 
call Dr. ___ office with any questions or concerns. Please 
follow the instructions below.

General instructions:
* Take your medications as prescribed.
* Do not drive while taking narcotics.
* Take a stool softener such as colace while taking narcotics to 
prevent constipation.
* Do not combine narcotic and sedative medications or alcohol.
* Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs.
* No strenuous activity until your post-op appointment.
* Nothing in the vagina for 4 weeks.
* No heavy lifting of objects >10 lbs for 4 weeks.
* You may eat a regular diet.
* You may walk up and down stairs.

Incision care:
* You may shower.
* Please use ___ bath (or take a bath) three times daily for 
soaking.

Call your doctor for:
* fever > 100.4F
* severe abdominal pain
* difficulty urinating
* vaginal bleeding requiring >1 pad/hr
* abnormal vaginal discharge
* redness or drainage from incision
* nausea/vomiting where you are unable to keep down fluids/food 
or your medication

To reach medical records to get the records from this 
hospitalization sent to your doctor at home, call ___.

You are being discharged with antibiotics. Please take as 
prescribed.

Brief Hospital Course:
.
In brief, Mr. ___ is a ___ year old gentleman with a history 
of metastatic prostate cancer on mitoxantrone who initially 
presented with malaise, sore throat, and fevers. Prior to his 
admission on ___, he was seen in the ED ___ for these 
complaints and was discharged to home with a prescription for 
azithromycin. However, his symptoms failed to improve after 
treatment so he re-presented to the ED on ___. In the ED, he 
received cefepime, vanco, and fluconazole as he had recently 
been neutropenic and was admitted to OMED on ___. On 
admission, he was initially treated with vancomycin and cefepime 
which was narrowed to cefepime alone when he was found to be 
not-neutropenic. There was no obvious source of infection with 
normal U/A and CXR. His regular dose of prednisone was held.  
.  
On the evening of ___, patient had a witnessed aspiration 
event with associated hypoxia. CXR confirmed new infiltrate at ___ 
lung base. He was treated for presumed aspiration pneumonitis in 
the ICU. He was cotinued on cefepime alone. He was ruled out for 
flu with DFA and all cultures remained negative including urine 
legionella Ag. He received aggressive chest ___ and O2 was weaned 
to RA. He had a swallow evaluation which cleared him for a 
pureed diet which was started. He had SBP readings in the ___, 
although asymptomatic, and he received IVF with SBP to 100s. He 
received a total of 1.5 L NS during his MICU stay. Labs during 
his MICU stay revealed an increase in WBC count (4->7), 
significant bandemia of 42%, slight Hct drop (stable on repeat), 
and stable thrombocytopenia. A random cortisol was checked and 
was 29.  
.  
On transfer back to the floor the patient is breathing 
comfortably on room air. Notes he ate new diet without problem. 
He denies any current fevers, chills, chest pain, SOB, abdominal 
pain, nausea, vomiting, or any other concerns.  
.
# Aspiration: Patient was continued on cefpodoxime for 5 more 
days, he was seen by  speech and swallow and his diet was nectar 
thickened liquids.  
.  
# Prostate cancer: Patient's prednisone was held while concern 
for infection, then restarted on the day of discharge.  There 
was no chemo given during the hospitalization, patient was 
followed up as an outpatient
- Tx as per outpatient oncology team  
- restart prednisone tomorrow  
.
# Code: Full code (confirmed with pt)  
.  
# Dispo: social work was consulted prior to discharge for help 
with patient coping as he felt concerned about his functional 
decline.  Home services were set up for this patient.

You came to the hospital with sore throat, fever and difficulty 
swallowing.  We treated you with antibiotics.  You apirated on 
your food and this caused you to have difficulty breathing.  We 
transferred you to the ICU and you did well and came back to the 
floor.  You were able to breathe well without oxygen.  Our 
physical therapists worked with you and found you were safe and 
ready to go home.  
.
We made the following changes to your medications:
Added Cefpodoxime for 4 more days 
.
We had our speech and swallow team evaluate you and they 
recommended that you have a thick liquid diet, they will send 
someone to your home to help you with your diet.

symptoms that are concerning to you please call your doctor or

Brief Hospital Course:
Summary:
___ ___ Army veteran with PMHx of chronic homelessness, 
depression, chronic poly-substance use (alcohol, crack/cocaine, 
marijuana/K2), alcohol withdrawal, multiple ED visits for 
alcohol intoxication, reported recurrent suicidality while 
intoxicated, multiple incarcerations, who presented with alcohol 
intoxication, found to be increasingly somnolent ___ ED requiring 
intubation for air protection, now extubated and transitioned to 
medical floor. Patient did well on phenobarbital taper, 
completed protocol through ___ step of downtitration (IV loading 
dose then 36mg BID x 2 days, 18mg BID x 2 days, 8mg BID x 2 
days). Patient diagnosed with aspiration PNA, sputum cultures 
grew community acquired MRSA and Strep PNA. Patient should 
complete planned 10 day course of levofloxacin 750mg QD through 
___ and doxycycline 100mg BID ___. Symptoms improving prior to 
discharge. Patient developed RUQ tenderness and diarrhea while 
admitted, worse when eating. C.diff was negative, HIV negative, 
LFTs were normal, cholelithiasis noted on U/S with no evidence 
of cholecystitis. Symptoms improved with Creon tabs with meals. 
Patient's previously prescribed psychiatric regimen was 
restarted and patient discharged with fluoxetine 40mg QAM, 
risperidone 6mg QHS, trazodone 200mg QHS PRN. Patient discharged 
with plan to go to ___ after bedside delivery 
of one month of medication (except antibiotics as noted) and 
will re-present to ___ on ___. PCP and psychiatric follow 
up were encouraged.
 
# Alcohol withdrawal: Patient with chronic alcohol abuse and 
multiple ED admissions for alcohol intoxications. Per records 
reviews, he has history of alcohol withdrawal. Endorses history 
of withdrawal seizures. Serum ethanol level on presentation was 
538. The patient demonstrated signs and symptoms of alcohol 
withdrawal after extubation and removal of sedation. He was 
started on a phenobarbital taper and has responded well. Started 
on high dose thiamine for 3 days with transition to 100mg QD, 
multivitamins and folic acid. Social work was consulted and 
coordinated resources and housing options. 
 
# MRSA and Strep Pneumonia: Retrocardiac infiltrate on CXR, 
initially not treated given lack of infectious symptoms. 
Developed cough after extubation, spiked fevers on ___ and 
developed a leukocytosis on ___. He was started on levofloxacin 
for presumed CAP. Strep and MRSA on sputum culture. Patient 
should complete planned 10 day course of levofloxacin 750mg QD 
through ___ and doxycycline 100mg BID ___. Symptoms improving 
prior to discharge.
  
# Diarrhea: large volume liquid stools reported, C.diff 
negative. No leukocytosis, fevers, cramping, reported bleeding 
or melena. Has RUQ tenderness with cholelithiasis without 
evidence of cholecystitis, LFTs and lipase WNL. Denies IVDU 
history. HIV negative. RUQ U/S without evidence of cirrhosis, 
focal lesions, cholecystitis. Symptoms improved with trial of 
Creon. 
 
# Depression / Hx suicide attempt: Patient has outpatient 
Psychiatrist and treated at ___, reports long term use of 
fluoxetine, risperidone, and takes trazodone 200mg QHS for 
insomnia. Mood was stable and no suicidality. Per ___ records: 
active Rx for fluoxetine and risperidone by Dr. ___ 
(Psych). Restarted on fluoxetine 40mg QAM and risperidone 6mg 
QHS prior to discharge. 
 
# Altered mental status: Resolved. Patient was noted to have 
increased somnolence ___ context of polysubstance abuse. Tox 
screen was positive for cocaine, alcohol, benzo. CT head showed 
no acute intracranial abnormality. ABG ___ the ED was notable for 
normal O2, but Co2 was not measured; repeat ABG ___ MICU was 
within normal limits. Most likely etiology is ethanol 
intoxication. Infection may also have contributed to 
presentation.  
 
# Elevated lactate: Lactate was found to be 5 on admission. 
Patient was hemodynamically stable and not requiring any 
pressors. There is no evidence of ischemic (extremities were 
warm, no tenderness upon palpation of abdomen). Elevated lactate 
was thought to be secondary to thiamine deficiency. The patient 
was treated with high dose thiamine and IVF with improvement ___ 
lactate. 
 
 
TRANSITIONAL ISSUES
===================
- Patient should complete 10 day course of levofloxacin 750mg QD 
through ___ and doxycycline 100mg BID ___
- Patient restarted on previously prescribed fluoxetine 40mg QAM 
and risperidone 6mg QHS and PRN trazodone 200mg QHS for insomnia
- Patient started on Creon tabs TID AC for presumed chronic 
pancreatic insufficiency given good response of diarrheal 
symptoms

You also were found to have a pneumonia (infection ___ your

You are being sent home with oral antibiotics that you should 
take every day until you finish the prescription, even if you 
feel better before then. 

You also had a lot of diarrhea that was improved before 
discharge. You should take the Creon pills (contain enzymes from 
your pancreas) with each meal to help you avoid the pain and 
diarrhea you described that got worse with eating.
 
Finally, we restarted your Prozac and Risperdal that had been 
prescribed to you earlier ___ the year by Dr. ___. 

Please follow up with your primary care physician and with Dr. 
___. 

If you get worsening fevers, chills, cough, abdominal pain,

return to the hospital immediately.

cancer s/p cycle 2 of cisplatin on ___, with concurrent 
radiation therapy, presents with fever, vomiting. 
.
Patient was most recently hospitalized on ___ for vomiting. 
At that time there was no evidence of bowel obstruction. His 
nausea was controlled with antiemetics. He was discharged on 
metoclopramide on ___. 
.
On ___ he was started on fentanyl patch 50 mcg/hr for 
odynophagia. Patient continues to complain of ___ pain on 
swallowing and ___ pain when not swallowing. On ___ he had 
an acute episode of vomiting after infusing Ensure via G tube. 
He denies nausea and is taking reglan metoclopramide three times 
a day as prescribed. He denies abdominal pain, diarrhea, or 
constipation--is baseline is one bowel movement every other day. 
He has not used the G tube since. He has been passing gas; his 
last bowel movement was 2 days ago. No fever, chill, dysuria. At 
baseline he has a chronic dry cough from throat irritation. No 
sick contact or recent travel.
.
At radiation clinic on ___, the day of admission, patient was 
orthostatic with upright BP 94/62 and supine BP 74/58, upright 
HR 104 and supine HR 92. His temperature was 100.5 F, weight 159 
lbs. WBC was 1.4, down from 2.2. the day before. After his 
radiation treatment, he received 500 ml D5NS IV and was 
transfered to the ___ ED. 
.
In the ED, T 100.0, HR 90, BP 111/68, RR 18, 100%RA. WBC was 
1.6. CXR was unremarkable. He received acetaminophen, 
ondansetron, and IV metoclopramide. 
.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ man with history of oropharyngeal and hypopharyngeal 
cancer s/p cycle 2 of cisplatin on ___, with concurrent 
radiation therapy, presents with fever, vomiting, weight loss, 
worsening leukopenia. The patient was recently discharged from a 
hospitalization for nausea and vomiting felt to be secondary to 
treatment related gastroparesis that improved with addition of 
metoclopromide. He has treatment related odynophagia that is 
managed with percocet per g tube.
.
# Fever and neutropenia: The patient was not yet neutropenic on 
admission and antibiotics were initially held. Admission CXR, 
KUB, and cultures were all negative for an infectious source. 
The patient remained febrile however, became absolutely 
neutropenic, and was started on Cefepime. On ___, the patient 
continued to have fevers and became mildly hypotensive with SBP 
in the low 90's, but appeared well. Repeat CXR and blood 
cultures were obtained and a fluid bolus was given. Vancomycin 
was added at this time based on his treatment-related 
mucositis.Pt remained with febile neutropni fo rmore than 3 days 
adn flagyl was added for anaerob coverage in teh setting of 
mucositis. Fluconazole was increased to a dose of 400 mg 
___  defervesed on ___ and neutropenia resolved on 
___. Antibiotics were discontinued 24 hrs after resolution 
of neutropenia and fever and pt remained afebrile.All blood 
cutures and urine cutures were negative.
# Vomiting: The patient had been taking Ensure plus as a bolus 
per G tube as an outpatient, but vomited a portion the day of 
admission. Admission KUB was negative for obstruction and he was 
treated with antiemetics and continued on metoclopromide for 
gastroparesis. After discussion with the nutrition service, he 
was restarted on ___ dilution, low volume, continuous tube feeds 
with the aim of increasing his hourly volume as tolerated. 
Although he clearly tolerated the dilute continuous feeds better 
than the bolus, tube feeds were intermittantly held when he felt 
nauseated and obstructed. Prioir to discharge bolus feedings 
were resumed an dpt tolerated them well.
# Oropharyngeal cancer with treatment related 
odynophagia/mucositis: The patient was in the midst of getting 
concurrent cisplatin with radiation. He continued his radiation 
as scheduled during his admission. The patient had been managing 
his pain with a fentenyl patch and percocet. Fentanyl patch dose 
was increased to 75 mcg/hr and for breakthrough pain patinet was 
started on dialudid IV , although he required at most 2 doses 
/24 hrs. Pt was also started on the oncologic mix prn and 
fluconazole for the mucositis/thrush.Pt completed his radiation 
treatment during his hospital stay . He did not get his last 
dose of cisplatin as he was still neutropenic at the time.
#Superficial Venous thrombi: Pt had a left picc line place 
becauase of poor peripheral venous access. Pt developed redness 
and swelling o fleft arm and left upper extremity u/s showed a 
clot in the basilic and cephalic veins. The picc line was 
removed and pt was started on therapeutic lovenox.During 
hospital saty erythema and swelling improved significantly. Pt 
to complete a 2 week course of lovenox.  

# FEN: TF via G tube, IVF
.
# Ppx: Heparin SQ, swichted to therapeutic lovenox as above..
# Code: full

Dear ___,  

___ was a pleasure taking care of you at ___ 
___.  

WHY WAS I ADMITTED TO THE HOSPITAL?  
- You were admitted to the hospital because you had 
lightheadedness and a slow heart rate

WHAT HAPPENED WHILE I WAS IN THE HOSPITAL?  
- You were kept on a heart monitor to evaluate the rhythm in 
your heart and were found to have a block in the electricity of 
your heart
- You had an ultrasound and MRI of your heart that were normal
- You had a pacemaker put in to prevent your heart from going 
too slow

WHAT SHOULD I DO WHEN I GO HOME?  
- You should continue to take your medications as prescribed. 
- If you are experiencing new or concerning chest pain that is 
coming and going you should call the heartline at ___. 
If you are experiencing persistent chest pain that isnt getting 
better with rest or nitroglycerine you should call ___.  
- You should also call the heartline if you develop swelling in 
your legs, abdominal distention, or shortness of breath at 
night.
- You should attend the appointments listed below.

FINDINGS:  There are multiple small nonenhancing T2 
hyperintensities throughout the liver, likely biliary hamartomas 
and/or simple cysts. There are few subcentimeter ares within the 
liver which are hyperenhancing on arterial phase but do not 
persist in other sequences (15:22, 27). There is small amount of 
perihepatic free fluid and tiny amount of free fluid is seen in 
the right paracolic gutter. The gallbladder is unremarkable.

choledocholithiasis.  The pancreas is of normal signal

surrounding fat stranding or fluid collections to suggest acute 
inflammation.  The adrenal glands are unremarkable.  The spleen 
is within normal limits.   There are tiny nonenhancing T2 
hyperintense foci in the left kidney, likely simple renal cysts. 
The kidneys otherwise enhance symmetrically without 
hydronephrosis or masses.

unremarkable. The intraabdominal aorta and its branches are 
patent.  There is no lymphadenopathy.

perihepatic free fluid and tiny amount of fluid in the right 
paracolic gutter.

Brief Hospital Course:
# pancreatitis, acute
Ms ___ is a ___ yo woman with history of osteoporosis, past 
medication related transaminase elevation, and NSAID gastritis, 
who presented with 1 day duration of acute epigastric pain 
accompanied by vomiting and diarrhea.  She was found to have 
Lipase elevation to 2462 in the ED, consistent with 
pancreatitis. She was admitted for bowel rest and IV fluids, and 
her pain, nausea and diarrhea all self-resolved without any 
medications or interventions. She was afebrile, denied any 
alcohol use, and her liver enzymes, CBC, chemistries, 
triglycerides and calcium were all WNL. She was seen by 
gastroenterology, who recommended RUQ U/S and MRCP. Imaging were 
negative for stones or pancreatic abnormalities, and only 
remarkable for incidental findings of small liver cysts vs 
biliary hamartomas.  Her diet was advanced, and she tolerated 
this well by discharge. Her transient symptoms were likely due 
to gall stone passage. She did endorse taking a weight loss 
nutritional supplement Garcinia, which may have actions on the 
pancreas. Uncertain if this may have contributed to her 
symptoms, so she is counseled to discontinue this supplement. 
She is also counseled to avoid alcohol and fatty foods, and 
follow up with GI clinic.

The patient with newly diagnosed gastric mass was admitted to

which went well without complication (please see the Operative

the patient arrived on the floor NPO with IV fluids, with Foley 
catheter, and  IV Dilaudid for pain control. The patient was 
hemodynamically stable.

secondary to nausea caused by Oxycodone. 
At the time of discharge on POD 2, the patient was doing well, 
afebrile with stable vital signs. The patient was tolerating a 
regular diet, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain 
was well controlled. The patient received discharge teaching and 
follow-up instructions with understanding verbalized and 
agreement with the discharge plan.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ man with PMHx of severe iron deficiency anemia, 
oligometastatic colon cancer s/p colectomy and partial liver 
resection (now in remission), prior small intestinal bleeds, 
HTN/HLD, and PE on apixaban admitted for persistent dyspnea most 
likely multi-factorial in nature, with major component due to 
severe iron deficiency anemia and mild hypervolemia. Received 2U 
pRBC and IV iron infusion as well as IV Lasix x1. Symptoms 
improved with reassuring oxygenation and so discharged home with 
plan for PCP follow up.

# DYSPNEA
Presented for persistent exertional dyspnea that has been 
ongoing problem for weeks-months. Likely multifactorial 
including subacutely worse anemia, underlying moderate pulmonary 
hypertension with mild hypervolemia, emphysema, as well as 
anxiety. Mildly volume overload on exam though without evidence 
of acute decompensated heart failure, proBNP negative. EKG and 
troponins reassuring. Overall low concern for recurrent 
pulmonary embolism as dyspnea is more sub-acute / chronic in 
nature and was without significant hypoxia at rest or with 
exertion. Received 2U pRBC and IV iron infusion. Further 
received 40 IV Lasix x1 for mild volume overload. Symptoms 
overall improved and so discharged home with plan for increased 
maintenance Lasix dose until PCP follow ___ require ongoing 
treatment for persistent anemia in setting of iron deficiency 
and likely chronic slow GI bleeding.

# ANEMIA
# Hx GI BLEEDING
Likely component of slow GI losses given history of small bowel 
angioectasias and iron deficiency anemia refractory to home iron 
supplementation. No evidence of acute or emergent GI bleed- no 
hemoptysis, melena, BRBPR. Also with possible contribution from 
reported history of beta thalassemia though unclear to what 
extent this is responsible for symptoms. Of note is systemically 
anti-coagulated for prior PE though no evidence of significant 
acute blood loss. s/p 2U pRBC during admission as well as IV 
iron infusion. Continued home oral iron supplement at discharge.

# HYPONATREMIA
Likely hypervolemic related to held Lasix doses. Received 40 IV 
Lasix x1. Discharged on 40 mg Po Lasix daily.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

It was a pleasure taking care of you at ___.

Why you were in the hospital:
- worsening shortness of breath
- low red blood cell levels

What was done for you in the hospital:
- We gave you an iron infusion through the IV
- We gave you two blood transfusions to improve your red blood 
cell counts
- We obtained blood tests and an EKG. The results were 
reassuring and showed that there was no recent damage to your 
heart to account for your shortness of breath.
- We gave you IV Lasix to help remove extra fluid from your 
body.

What you should do when get you get home:
- Check your weight when you get home and monitor every day 
thereafter. If rising more than 3 lbs please contact your PCP to 
discuss your Lasix dose.
- Call your regular doctor ___ to schedule an appointment 
within 1 week of discharge - see details below in the 
appointments section.
- Take your medications as detailed in the discharge papers.
- Monitor for worsening symptoms and call your doctor or return 
to the hospital if concerned.

We wish you the best!

Sincerely,
Your ___ Care Team

However, he feels that he would be fine to leave the hospital at

difficulty as a function of the severity of his symptoms. He was 
unable to keep track of what was told to him by his treatment 
team. His insight and judgement was severly impaired.  He is 
aware that guardianship has been applied for to have his parents 
appointed an alternate decision maker. He does not oppose this.

Brief Hospital Course:
# LEGAL: ___
# PSYCHIATRIC:   Upon return to the inpatient psychiatry service 
on ___, collateral from the parents and ___ team 
revealed that patient would show some improvement with ativan if 
he consistently received it.  However, when he would refuse 
ativan he did he became more catatonic. Patient was started on 
scheduled ativan, which he could not refuse due to possibility 
of irreversible harm given his persistent catatonic state. It 
was administered IM for his safety, despite the lack of court 
commitment or guardianship at that time. His parents were in 
agreement with this plan as they observed over and over how 
necessary ativan was for ___ to remain conscious 
consistently. Ultimately guardianship was obtained by his 
parents and the patient was committed on a section 7,8,8b.  His 
maximum dosing of ativan during admission was 2 mg q 4 hour. As 
Mr. ___ continued to remain catatonic despite ativan dosing 
and continued to struggle in consistently eating his meals, 
consistently drinking fluids, was unable to consistently accept 
pills of ativan (struggled with pill compliance outside of a 
hospital as well), was unable to participate in sustained 
conversations or in structured groups and remained in such 
danger of ongoing decompensation from his illness, permission to 
begin ECT was sought from the court on a section 7,8,8b.  The 
role of ECT in severe catatonia was discussed with the patient 
and his family and was assessed to be his best chance at 
stabilizing and being able to return home with his parents 
safely back to ___. Dr. ___, and 
anesthesia were all consulted, in addition to Dr. ___ 
unit director. With ECT treatment, under the care of Dr. 
___, Mr. ___ did indeed show significant improvement 
in his symptoms. He was able to tend to his hygiene, eat his 
meals regularly, speak spontaneously with the team, socialize in 
the milieu, attend groups, and participate in enjoyable 
activities. As his catatonia improved with ECT, he was found to 
be more sedated with some signs of ativan intoxication and the 
dose of ativan was ultimately reduced to 2mg TID. 

While on the ___ service, abilify had been started to work 
to target his psychotic symptoms. He had a prior good response 
to abilify when psychiatrically hospitalized in ___. With 
abilify, ativan, and the completion of ECT #11 the patient 
appeared to have reached maximum benefit from ECT. Where no 
further improvement was seen and his parents had felt that he 
returned very much to his baseline. In general, he had tolerated 
ECT well with few side effects, but towards the end of the 
course did present as having more short term confusion, 
sedation, and forgetfullness around the ECT treatments. Despite 
dramatic improvement with ECT, ___ did remain slowed in 
response latency, demonstrated reduced expression of thought 
content, psychomotor slowing, and a generalized negativism. This 
always appeared less when he was engaged in enjoyable activity 
on the unit or visiting with his family.  A trial of a lower 
dose of ativan to 1mg TID was attempted to rule out sedation as 
being a cause, but this appeared to increase the slowing, so 
this was increased back to ativan 2mg TID (higher doses had 
appeared sedating). In efforts to treat residual psychosis, 
abilify was increased to 30mg daily, but this also did not 
appear to make a significant impact.  Ultimately abilfy 20mg po 
daily was continued and appeared to be the best dose to target 
some residual mild auditory hallucinations without increasing 
slowing. However, he did have some increased tone in his upper 
extremities that was not present on the lower dose of abilify. 
This should continue to be monitored through time and a lower 
dose of abilify could again be considered.  

At time of discharge, Mr. ___ was free of symptoms of 
depression. He was able to reflect back to a time when he had 
been feeling depressed with suicidal thoughts in the time period 
before his hospitalization at ___. He had reflected on a 
past feeling that he was very sick, had cancer, and was going to 
die, so he had thoughts at ending his own life. At time of 
discharge there was no evidence of suicidal thoughts, he 
appeared future oriented, and appeared motivated to continue to 
work towards goals of trying to work again or return to school. 
He felt healthy, back to himself, and no longer feared cancer of 
physical ailments. Through out his admission, his connection to 
and love for his family was apparent and appeared to be his most 
significant protective factor. At time of discharge, ___ 
denied auditory and visual hallucinations. He could reflect back 
to past symptoms of prominent voices, outside of his head that 
he experienced as commentary of his thoughts and actions. These 
voices were mixed with sound and at worst happened frequently 
through the day. Prior to discharge they lasted seconds 
infrequently, and this appeared to resolve with abilfy 20mg 
daily, but will continue to need to be monitored closely 
ultimately for effectiveness and ongoing tolerability. This has 
been his only antipsychotic trial thus far. 

At his worst, he had prominent visual hallucinations, for 
example seeing a fly which came and went during his catatonia 
based upon what he was saying and what the voices were saying. 
When he presented to the inpatient unit initally he was 
significantly internally preoccupied. Sitting or standing 
staring at the wall or ceiling for prolonged periods of time. 
This had resolved by time of discharge, but at times still 
appeared distracted for brief periods of time.

Mr. ___ remains at risk of relapse into psychotic and 
catatonic symptoms through time. At this time, he appears safe 
and appropriate to transition home with his family back to ___ with ongoing close follow up. His risk to himself has 
been reduced by a number of modalities: 1. The significant 
improvement of his symptoms and the resolution of his severe 
catatonia leading to medical instability with ECT treatment with 
the plan of a taper of ECT through time. 2. By continuing on 
oral ativan as evidence favors ongoing ativan use vs slow taper 
through time, 3. Antipsychotic use to treat his psychotic 
disorder 4. His parents being appointed ___ Guardians for 
appropriate decision making as ___ continues to have 
impaired insight and judgement overall and was not able to 
follow through on his treatment prior to this hospitalization in 
the past. Legal department states this guardianship would be 
recognized in ___. 5. The ongoing close monitoring of 
his health and behavior by his parents who are very thoughtful 
about his care and very dedicated to his ongoing health. 6. 
___ current commitment to sobriety and the amount of 
education provided regarding the dangers of drugs and alcohol. 
7. The reconnection to mental health follow up in ___. 

Although, it would be most ideal for ___ to transition 
directly to a partial hospital program or day program, this is 
not possible given his current lack of Medicaid. His parents are 
able and trustworthy to take him to emergency care should he 
show signs of relapse in a less structured environment. 

Diagnosis: While at ___ he had a medical 
evaluation that included the following:  MRI, EEG, LP, ___, 
RPR, LFTs, and ammonia level - all of this was unremarkable. He 
had multiple physical exams by medical doctors at ___ and 
here at ___ that did not reveal an organic basis to his 
catatonia outside of mental illness and substance abuse. while 
at ___ NMDA-R ab was obtained and it was negative, Thyroid was 
normal, in addition to urine studies. History and presentation 
has consistently pointed to likely schizophrenia with comorbid 
ecstasy abuse as the primary cause of his acute catatonia and 
psychosis. He was reported to have a normal developmental 
history by his pediatrician. Although he is reported to be at 
baseline by family, his presentation at discharge appears to be 
related to residual effects of ecstasy versus negative symptoms 
associated with psychotic disorder vs residual symptoms of 
catatonia that have not responded to ECT or ativan. ___ was 
drawn and is currently pending. This is expected to be negative. 
Final results will be forwarded to outpatient providers. It is 
also recommended that the patient have a complete neurologic 
exam by a pediatric neurologist and a complete slit lamp eye 
exam. Although his CERULOPLASMIN level was normal at 20. It will 
also be helpful to follow up with his pediatrician who has known 
him through his whole life to judge if he has returned to his 
known baseline.

# MEDICAL:
Hemodynamincs/Volume status:  Patient had a known history of 
hemodynamic instability, which was responsive to IV hydration, 
and laboratory abnormalities (rise in Cr and AST) when catatonic 
and unable to keep up with his nutritional and volume needs. 
Given concern for prior hemodynamic instability, patient's 
orthostatics were monitored.  Although patient was initially 
able to eat, once his catatonia became more incapacitating he 
was started on IVFs.  At times, he had sinus tachycardia and 
repolarization abnormalities.  Cardiology consulted and cleared 
him for continued ECT without need for additional workup. At 
time of discharge his blood pressure and pulse remained normal 
for several weeks as his hydration status significantly 
improved. 

Urinary retention:  Patient was less interactive and bladder 
scans were initiated, which revealed urinary retention.  A foley 
 was placed and greater than 900 cc of urine was drained from 
patient's bladder.  Urine was noted to be concentrated and there 
was concern for sediment causing difficulty with drainage.  
Resolution of urinary symptoms upon return to inpatient 
psychiatry and there was no reoccurrence of difficulty once his 
catatonia resolved. 

Ophthomology: Patient denied visual problems through out his 
admission. Through out his time in the hospital he was found to 
have symmetrical mydriasis without clear etiology. This was 
present upon admission and remained essentially unchanged. He 
was also noted to have a reduced blink frequency and was 
observed to have times when he would sleep with his eyes open 
(when not catatonic ). Optho was consulted and they recommended 
outpatient evaluation  and lacrilube application to eyes for dry 
eyes and decreased blink
frequency. He should seek more urgent help should his eyes 
become red and/or irritated. 

# MILIEU:  No behavioral problems in the milieu.  As he became 
less catatonic, he was able to interact with other patients and 
initiate conversation. He participated in groups and was social 
with peers. 

# FAMILY/SOCIAL WORK: Team was consistently in contact with 
patient's family through out admission and worked to have his 
father and mother appointed guardians. Several family meetings 
were held. His parents were very dedicated to his care and came 
to visit him every day during his admission. They should 
continue to be closely involved in all medical decision making 
outside of the hospital. 

 
Medications on Admission:
None prior to admission to ___. 

Had been maintained on stool softeners, abilify,and ativan 
during admission to ___ service. 
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Aripiprazole 20 mg PO DAILY

#*30 Tablet Refills:*0
2. Lorazepam 2 mg PO TID 
RX *lorazepam [Ativan] 2 mg 1 tablet by mouth three times a day 
Disp #*90 Tablet Refills:*0
3. Artificial Tear Ointment 1 Appl BOTH EYES PRN dry eyes 
RX *artificial tear ointment [Nighttime Relief Eye]   1 
application application at bedtime Disp #*1 Tube Refills:*0

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Catatonia
Schizophrenia, catatonic type 
Ecstasy Abuse 

 
Discharge Condition:
Appearance: No apparent distress.  Young thin male with short
brown hair wearing comfortable clothing. 
Behavior: Some spontaneous movements. Seated comfortably.
Orients toward interviewing clinician. Eye contact less intense, 

Mood and Affect: 'good, relaxed'; restricted as at baseline,
less reactive than yesterday
Thought process: Linear, logical, concrete
Thought Content: remains somewhat impoverished, no overt
delusions, future oriented. 
Judgment and Insight: impaired, but improved from admission.
However does not appear as having complex decision making
capacity  
Speech: improved tone but still slightly monotone, decreased
latency in responses, volume improved. Responds in short
sentences. 
Language: No paraphasic errors. 
Attention: More attentive to conversation

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear ___,

As you know, you came to ___ for catatonia.  Your catatonia 
was so paralyzing, you were not able to care for yourself or 
make your own decisions.  We had to get the court and your 
parents involved to help make decisions for you.  They helped us 
to provide and you to obtain  the treatment you needed (ECT and 
ativan) to start interacting with your surroundings. 

As we have discussed, there are many reasons for catatonia, but 
psychosis and substance abuse are both common causes.  To treat 
your psychosis, you are on ability. To help prevent relapse and 
treat residual symptoms of catatonia you remain on ativan. ECT 
was a necessary treatment given the degree of your symptoms and 
it is currently being tapered. It is going to be very important 
for you to avoid substances in the future as they trigger 
recurrence of psychosis and catatonia.

Please follow up with all outpatient appointments as listed - 
take this discharge paperwork to your appointments.

Please continue all medications as directed.

Please avoid abusing alcohol and any drugs--whether prescription 
drugs or illegal drugs--as this can further worsen your medical 
and psychiatric illnesses.

Please contact your outpatient psychiatrist or other providers 
if you have any concerns.

Please call ___ or go to your nearest emergency room if you feel 
unsafe in any way and are unable to immediately reach your 
health care providers. Please go to your nearest emergency room 
if you again become catatonic.
 
We wish you the best of health,
Your ___ Mental Health Care Team
 
Followup Instructions:
___

"IMPRESSION:

CT CHEST (___):
"IMPRESSION: 
1. Diffuse irregularity of the bronchial tree with traction 
bronchiectasis in the left upper lobe.  Diffuse reticulation 
throughout the lungs. Findings could reflect fibrotic NSIP or 
chronic sequelae of hypersensitivity pneumonitis.  No prior 
chest CTs available for comparison. Patient appears to be status 
post right upper lobe and lower lobe VATS wedge resections. 
Therefore correlation with findings on pathology is recommended. 

2. Patchy peribronchial consolidative opacities in the bilateral 
upper lobes could represent superimposed pneumonia.  Clinical 
correlation is recommended. 
3.  Trace pneumomediastinum is likely related to patient's 
interstitial lung disease. 
4. Mild mediastinal and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy."

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ gentleman with a history of bipolar 
disorder and hypersensitivity pneumonitis who presented with 
acute dyspnea and cough in the setting of progressively 
worsening dyspnea over the last ___s concern for 
medication non-compliance for his bipolar disease. He reported

progressive worsening SOB with exertion and eventually at rest 
since that event, but on the day prior to admission, that SOB 
increased significantly and he developed a cough productive of 
sputum. Based upon CXR and leukocytosis, there was concern for 
CAP that was treated with doxycycline (no QT prolongation). CT 
demonstrated concern for diffuse irregularity of the bronchial 
tree and potential superimposed pneumonia c/w known 
hypersensitivity pneumonitis, which has been followed at ___. 
The patient's SOB and cough improved on doxycycline. Steroids 
were deferred in the setting of concern for potential manic 
episode. Psych was consulted and they started him on quetiapine 
300mg PO QHS. He was placed on ___ and will be discharged 
to inpatient psychiatry with plan for pulmonary ___ in 
1mo.

hypoxemia, etc.)

#CAP, hypersensitivity pneumonitis:
Chest x-ray on the day of admission demonstrated patchy 
bilateral airspace opacities concerning for multifocal atypical 
pneumonia and he had an elevated WBC. He was started on 
doxycycline as it had lower risk of QT prolongation, and he 
would likely need antipsychotic medications. Ceftriaxone was not 
prescribed as this community acquired pneumonia could likely 
have been treated in the outpatient setting, but he required 
hospitalization for medication non-compliance for his BPD and 
was placed on a ___. CT chest was obtained as 
hypersensitivity pneumonitis history was unknown on admission, 
and it showed concern for ILD with superimposed pneumonia. In 
addition to a CAP, there is concern for flare of his 
hypersensitivity pneumonitis in the setting of brush fire 
exposure, but steroids were held in the setting of a potential 
manic episode and he has been saturating well at room air with 
improving dyspnea and cough. Pulmonology was consulted, but 
after they reviewed his outside record, they recommended 1mo 
___ with pulmonologist at ___ and agreed with plan for 
avoiding steroids. He will be discharged to psychiatry for 
management of his bipolar disorder. Per scheduling, he will need 
to obtain insurance prior to following up with outpatient 
pulmonary ___ in 1mo.

#BPD: Patient with known history of BPD and concern for 
medication non-compliance. Initially started on olanzapine 2.5mg 
BID, but transitioned to Seroquel 300mg PO QHS standing plus an 
additional 50mg PO Q8Hr prn anxiety/agitation.

between 135 to 114 on discharge. Urine legionella negative, LFTs 
normal. Recommend CBC ___ to continue to monitor.

Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital with acute appendicitis. You 
were taken to the operating room and had your appendix removed 
laparoscopically.  You tolerated the procedure well and are now 
being discharged home with the following instructions:
Please follow up at the appointment in clinic listed below. We 
also generally recommend that patients follow up with their 
primary care provider after having surgery. We have scheduled an 
appointment for you listed below.
ACTIVITY:
 
Do not drive until you have stopped taking pain medicine and 
feel you could respond in an emergency.
You may climb stairs. 
You may go outside, but avoid traveling long distances until you 
see your surgeon at your next visit.
Don't lift more than ___ lbs for ___ weeks. (This is about the 
weight of a briefcase or a bag of groceries.) This applies to 
lifting children, but they may sit on your lap.
You may start some light exercise when you feel comfortable.
You will need to stay out of bathtubs or swimming pools for a 
time while your incision is healing. Ask your doctor when you 
can resume tub baths or swimming.
 
HOW YOU MAY FEEL: 
You may feel weak or "washed out" a couple weeks. You might want 
to nap often. Simple tasks may exhaust you.
You may have a sore throat because of a tube that was in your 
throat during surgery.
You could have a poor appetite for a couple days. Food may seem 
unappealing.
All of these feelings and reactions are normal and should go 
away in a short time.  If they do not, tell your surgeon.
 
YOUR INCISION:
Tomorrow you may shower and remove the gauzes over your 
incisions. Under these dressings you have small plastic bandages 
called steristrips. Do not remove steri-strips for 2 weeks. 
(These are the thin paper strips that might be on your 
incision.) But if they fall off before that that's okay.
Your incisions may be slightly red around the stitches. This is 
normal.
You may gently wash away dried material around your incision.
Avoid direct sun exposure to the incision area.
Do not use any ointments on the incision unless you were told 
otherwise.
You may see a small amount of clear or light red fluid staining 
your dressing or clothes. If the staining is severe, please call 
your surgeon.
You may shower. As noted above, ask your doctor when you may 
resume tub baths or swimming.
 
YOUR BOWELS:
Constipation is a common side effect of narcotic pain 
medicaitons. If needed, you may take a stool softener (such as 
Colace, one capsule) or gentle laxative (such as milk of 
magnesia, 1 tbs) twice a day. You can get both of these 
medicines without a prescription.
If you go 48 hours without a bowel movement, or have pain moving 
the bowels, call your surgeon. 
 
PAIN MANAGEMENT:
It is normal to feel some discomfort/pain following abdominal 
surgery. This pain is often described as "soreness". 
Your pain should get better day by day. If you find the pain is 
getting worse instead of better, please contact your surgeon.
You will receive a prescription for pain medicine to take by 
mouth. It is important to take this medicine as directed. Do not 
take it more frequently than prescribed. Do not take more 
medicine at one time than prescribed. Do not drink alcohol or 
drive while taking narcotic pain medication.
Your pain medicine will work better if you take it before your 
pain gets too severe.
Talk with your surgeon about how long you will need to take 
prescription pain medicine. Please don't take any other pain 
medicine, including non-prescription pain medicine, unless your 
surgeon has said its okay.
If you are experiencing no pain, it is okay to skip a dose of 
pain medicine.
Remember to use your "cough pillow" for splinting when you cough 
or when you are doing your deep breathing exercises.
If you experience any of the following, please contact your 
surgeon:
- sharp pain or any severe pain that lasts several hours
- pain that is getting worse over time
- pain accompanied by fever of more than 101
- a drastic change in nature or quality of your pain
 
MEDICATIONS:
Take all the medicines you were on before the operation just as 
you did before, unless you have been told differently.
If you have any questions about what medicine to take or not to 
take, please call your surgeon.
 
DANGER SIGNS:
Please call your surgeon if you develop:
- worsening abdominal pain
- sharp or severe pain that lasts several hours
- temperature of 101 degrees or higher
- severe diarrhea
- vomiting
- redness around the incision that is spreading
- increased swelling around the incision
- excessive bruising around the incision
- cloudy fluid coming from the wound
- bright red blood or foul smelling discharge coming from the 
wound
- an increase in drainage from the wound
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
___ with HCV/EtOH cirrhosis and left eye trauma presenting 
intoxicated/withdrawing after left facial contusion during 
altercation.

#ALCOHOL INTOXICATION / WITHDRAWAL: CIWA>10 in ED, received 15mg 
of diazepam in ED. No history of DTs or seizures per patient. 
Required lorazepam ___ po every ___ during first 2 days of 
admission. No longer scoring on CIWA scale at the time of 
discharge. Received thiamine, MVI, folate while inpatient. 
Social work was consulted for addiction counseling.

#ALCOHOLIC / HBV+ HCV+ CIRRHOSIS: Per PCP report, physical exam, 
labs and imaging. Decompensated with encephalopathy on admission 
with some ascites. Labs reflective of chronic HBV carriage (with 
undetectable viral load), as well as HCV infection (VL 569,000, 
genotype 1a). His ascites was minimal so did not require 
diuretics or paracentesis. Found to have asterixis and altered 
mental status consistent with hepatic encephalopathy which 
improved and ultimately resolved as he was given Lactulose 30mL 
qid, titrated to ___.

#ALCOHOLIC HEPATITIS: Given ongoing heavy alcohol ingestion 
during weeks prior to admission, transaminasemia with ___ >2 
at time of admission. ___ scores: initially 9.5, peaked at 
23.2, 21 on discharge. Steroids never warranted given ___ 
score <32 at all times as well as contraindication given HCV an 
HBV.  Nutrition was consulted to provide teaching regarding 
proper diet.

#OCULAR ERYTHEMA/SECRETIONS: On third day of admission patient 
developed new bilateral ocular erythema and thick greenish 
secretions raising concern for conjunctivitis. Ophthalmology 
considered bacterial vs. chemical conjunctivitis (potential 
offenders were cyclopentolate and brimonidine which were 
discontinued) . Improved with PolymixinB-Bactrim eye drops. He 
received  prednisone eye drops for left eye to decrease 
inflammation. Was prescribed protective eye glasses on DC.

#CONCERN FOR LIVER MASS: Patient at risk for HCC given cirrhosis 
and HBV/HCV. 6mm lesion found on  admission RUQ US. Triphasic CT 
on ___ showed 1.9cm hypodensity concerning for HCC. F/u MRI 
showed hypodensity was likely perfusion defect (and 1.1cm lesion 
likely regenerative, but warrants future attention). 

#IRON DEFICIENCY ANEMIA: Hemoglobin was 8.8 on admission. 
Vitamin B12 >1500. Ferritin 28, Fe/TIBC<10% on admission. Was 
given ferric gluconate iv x2 during admission. 

#LEFT EYE TRAUMA/INTRAOCULAR HYPERTENSION: Experiencing pain in 
left eye upon admission. Reported history of left eye trauma 
complicated by intraocular bleed leading to hypertension in 
___ as confirmed by contacting glaucoma fellow at ___. 
Had been off eye drops for 2 weeks prior to admission. Per ___ 
glaucoma fellow, prognosis of his eyesight is guarded. Pain 
likely explained by increased intra-ocular pressure. Patient was 
restarted on glaucoma medications with improvement of  Now much 
improved at the time of discharge.

#HYPONATREMIA: Hyponatremia with nadir at 128 while inpatient 
likely due to hypovolemia in the setting of being NPO for 
imaging procedures. Repleted with LR boluses and continuous 
fluids. Was also seen by nutrition and given Ensure shakes x 2 
for meals. On discharge Na 130. 
 
#NODULAR OPACITIES:
CT showed nodular opacities within the lower lobes of the lungs 
bilaterally, which ___ reflect aspiration or bronchopneumonia. 
Clinical history and exam were not concerning for pneumonia.

#TRANSITIONAL
- Please follow up with new PCP and ___ as scheduled
  - Please check LFTs at appointment on ___ to ensure no further 
worsening of alcoholic hepatitis 
  - Continue to encourage proper nutrition
  - Ensure adherence to medication, and importance of lactulose 
to avoid encephalopathy
  - Repeat chest CT in ___ weeks as outpatient for f/u on chest 
nodules
 -Please refer patient to Liver Clinic at ___ for further 
follow-up.

Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary Diagnoses:
- Alcohol withdrawal
- Alcoholic hepatitis
- Chronic hepatitis B
- Chronic hepatitis C
- Cirrhosis
- Left eye trauma
- Bilateral conjunctivitis

Secondary Diagnoses:
- Iron deficiency anemia

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

You were admitted to ___ on ___ because of alcohol 
intoxication and trauma to your left eye. While you were here, 
you underwent a safe detox, given that you drank a lot of 
alcohol per day. We also determined that you were Hepatitis B 
and C positive. These are both infections that are associated 
with liver cancer. As a result, we did an CT and MRI (imaging 
study) of your liver that showed lesions concerning for cancer. 
As a result, you are scheduled to follow up in clinic to manage 
your liver health. In the meantime, please continue to take all 
your medications as prescribed. It is especially important to 
take the lactulose 4 times a day, or until you have ___ bowel 
movements- this will prevent toxins from building up in your 
blood and causing mental confusion.

We also treated your left eye with steroids to help decrease the 
inflammation surrounding your trauma. We also continued your 
glaucoma eye drops for the left eye and treated both eyes with 
antibiotic eye drops because they ___ have been infected. After 
discharge, you have been given a prescription for protective 
glasses to shield your functional right eye. You have a follow 
up appointment at ___ Eye and Ear on ___.

In addition to the liver clinic appointment and the Mass Eye and 
Ear appointment on ___, you are also scheduled to see a primary 
care provider at ___'s ___ on ___. It is VERY 
IMPORTANT that you make it to all of these appointments.

In addition to all these appointments, it is important that you 
do your best to stay sober and not drink alcohol. Drinking 
alcohol is extremely dangerous in a patient like you who has 
severe liver disease.

Thank you kindly for letting us take care of you.

Sincerely,
___ Medicine

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr ___ is a ___ with h/o prostate CA s/p resection and XRT, 
HTN and CKD on dialysis who presents with dysuria and reports of 
positive BCx from ___ clinic concerning for bacteremia.

ACTIVE ISSUES
# Bacteremia
The ___ clinic reported the observation of gram 
negative rods during his dialysis, and was referred to our 
hospital for further evaluation.  Of note, patient reported 
subjective fever, chill and burning during urination, consistent 
with bacteremia.  However, there is no symptoms of SIRS while he 
was on the floor.  Patient was given ceftriaxone and vancomycin 
initially, which was switched on the ___ day of admission to 
cefepime.  The blood culture and sensitivity study from the 
initial positive specimen grew pseudomonas aeruginosa, which was 
sensitive to levofloxacin (this external lab did not run 
sensitivities to cipro).  Patient was discharged with oral 
ciprofloxacin for 14 days.  During this admission, blood culture 
was obtained daily, which all remained negative.  Patient 
remained afebrile, with stable vital signs, and no leukocytosis.
OUTPATIENT ISSUES
-- Patient was asked to take Ciprofloxacin 500 mg daily for 14 
days

# Chronic kidney disease
Patient has history of chronic kidney disease, recently 
requiring hemodialysis.  Patient was scheduled to receive 
hemodialysis on M, W, F.  His medication was hemodialysis dosed. 
 He received dialysis during this hospitalization without 
complications.

CHRONIC ISSUES
Patient has a long history of hypertension, and was treated 
medically.  We continued his outpatient medication regimen, 
which was held on days of dialysis.  His blood pressure was 
monitored closely.  Patient also has documented history of 
hyperlipidemia, gout and detrussor instability.  The equivalent 
of his outpatient medication was provided, and patient tolerated 
without complication.

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES
-- Patient declares a full code.  
-- Patient has an appointment with Dr. ___ on ___ for 
followup.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

You came to our hospital from your ___ clinic for the 
presence of bacteria in your blood, likely from a urinary tract 
infection.  You have been initially treated with broad coverage 
antibiotics while you were in the hospital.  The micrology 
result from your ___ clinic came back positive for a 
bacteria called pseudomonas.  The rest of the blood cultures we 
obtained during your hospitalization have all remained negative. 
 You may go home to finish the treatment with antibiotics that 
will cover this bacteria.  You also received hemodialysis during 
this hospitalization, which you tolerated very well.

After going home, please take the following new medication:
-- Ciprofloxacin 500 mg one tablet a day for 14 days
-- You do not need to take nitrofurantoin.  But you may discuss 
that with your urologist.

There is no further changes to your medication or changes to 
your dialysis schedule.

Also, we made an appoitment for you with your primary care 
doctor,   (Please see below for more information)

It has been a privilege to take care you here at ___.  We wish 
you a speedy recovery.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ year old man with ___

ACUTE/ACTIVE PROBLEMS:
#Hematuria
#New bladder mass: On dual anti platelet therapy (DAPT) for 
stent and
presented to ___ with hematuria and found to have bladder mass 
on
imaging which needs biopsy/resection. S/p CBI without any 
further
bleeding on the time of transfer.  Here, he was seen by both 
Urology and Cardiology.  Cardiology stated that ideally, he 
should be on DAPT for 12 months, but given the fact that surgery 
would be absolutely prohibitive, they stated that he could be 
paused with Plavix for 5 days prior to surgery, suggesting that 
this be done inside the hospital, and then have it restarted 
immediately post-op.  This would occurrr in about 6 weeks.  He 
would never stop his aspirin.  Since there was no immediate need 
for procedure, he had no interventions at this time.  Urine was 
ordered for cytology, but results were not back at time of 
discharge.  He also had resolved hematuria, so foley cath was 
successfully removed without complication. He was discharged 
home on alpha blocker (Doxazosin) as well as Flomax and will 
follow-up with Urology as an outpatient for surgical planning.  

#CAD s/p new stent ___: Not currently having active chest
pain, likely pressure symptoms over the past few days are 
anxiety
related as he has had trops neg x 3. He continued on aspirin, 
Plavix, isosorbide mononitrate, metoprolol and his home 
Simvastatin.

#Hypothyroidism: continue levothyroxine

#DMII: hold metformin, but restarted upon discharge.  

#Depression/Anxiety: continue sertraline, lamictal, clonazepam

I spent > 30 min in discharge planning and coordination of care.

that you should be on Plavix and Aspirin for at least 3 months

Your ___ Team

Discharge Instructions:
Discharge Instructions: Please call your surgeon or return to 
the emergency department if you develop a fever greater than 
101.5, chest pain, shortness of breath, severe abdominal pain, 
pain unrelieved by your pain medication, severe nausea or 
vomiting, severe abdominal bloating, inability to eat or drink, 
foul smelling or colorful drainage from your incisions, redness 
or swelling around your incisions, or any other symptoms which 
are concerning to you.

Diet: Stay on Stage 3 diet until your follow up appointment. Do 
not self advance diet, do not drink out of a straw or chew gum.

Medication Instructions:
Resume your home medications, CRUSH ALL PILLS.
You will be starting some new medications:
1.  You are being discharged on medications to treat the pain 
from your operation. These medications will make you drowsy and 
impair your ability to drive a motor vehicle or operate 
machinery safely. You MUST refrain from such activities while 
taking these medications.
2. You should begin taking a chewable complete multivitamin with 
minerals. No gummy vitamins.
3. You will be taking omeprazole 40 mg mg twice daily. This 
medicine prevents gastric reflux and your ulcer.
4. You will be taking carafate 4 times a day but 2 hours after 
your omeprazole in the morning and evening.
5. You should take a stool softener, Colace, twice daily for 
constipation as needed, or until you resume a normal bowel 
pattern.
6. You must not use NSAIDS (non-steroidal anti-inflammatory 
drugs) Examples are Ibuprofen, Motrin, Aleve, Nuprin and 
Naproxen. These agents will cause bleeding and ulcers in your 
digestive system.

Activity:
No heavy lifting of items ___ pounds for 6 weeks. You may 
resume moderate exercise at your discretion, no abdominal 
exercises.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

and

pharyngeal mass nearly occluding the airway, and the Pt was 
therefore taken to the operating room to safely secure his 
airway. He underwent awake fiberoptic intubation, direct 
laryngoscopy with biopsy, and drainage of the retropharyngeal 
cyst on ___. The cyst contained dark brown fluid consistent 
with hematoma. Please see the operative report for further 
details. The Pt was transferred to the PACU in stable condition 
and then returned to the SICU for further monitoring. He was 
subsequently extubated without difficulty, and reported that the 
dysphagia was gone. A follow-up CT of the neck showed resolution 
of the retropharngeal cyst. The Pt was eating and drinking 
normally and desired discharge. He had no complaints of 
dysphagia, respiratory distress, or any other concerns from a 
cardiac, pulmonary, GI, or GU standpoint. He was discharged home 
on augmentin 875mg bid x 10 days.
