Brief Hospital Course:
Mrs. ___ is a ___ year old woman with history of Graves (now 
hypothyroidism on synthroid), IgG Lambda Myeloma and Secondary 
Amyloidosis (s/p auto transplant ___, on Daratumumab), 
Depression, ESRD (on PD), Chronic Anemia (on epo), who presented
to ED from clinic with tachycardia, found to have new AFib and 
worsening anemia. Afib improved after blood transfusion and rate 
control with beta blocker. No obvious trigger other than anemia. 


#New Afib
Presented with new afib/RVR, which converted to sinus after 
blood transfusion and rate control with metoprolol. Patient 
underwent work-up for new afib, which was overall unrevealing. 
Anemia was a possible trigger. Her TSH and free T4 were wnl, 
although TSH toward lower end of normal and T4 toward upper end, 
suggesting she might tolerate a lower thyroid replacement dose 
and have less tendency toward afib. Trop elevation felt to 
result from mild demand in setting of ESRD, but not ACS. No PE 
on VQ scan, and TTE overall unrevealing. Her CHADS2VASC score 
was 2, and due to perceived increase in thrombotic risk due to 
amyloid, she was started on a heparin bridge to coumadin while 
on the ___ service, and transferred to ___ to complete this 
course. After being transferred to the ___ service the patient 
and her husband further questioned the decision to anticoagulate 
and the decision to bridge. In consultation with hem-onc, renal, 
and cardiology, this was felt to be a difficult risk-benefit 
assessment given her multiple factors potentially contributing 
to thrombotic risk and also to bleeding risk, including her 
amyloid and ESRD. Once multiple discussions occurred the patient 
opted to continue coumadin without further bridging, which was 
felt to be a medically reasonable choice. She was referred to 
the ___ clinic, who will contact her tomorrow to 
arrange further care. She was discharged on 5 mg daily, which 
seemed to be approximately the correct dosing based on her 
initial trajectory. She was also discharged on metoprolol 
succinate 12.5. 

#?Abdominal wall hematoma
The day of discharge the patient developed a nodular firm lesion 
on the lower right abdominal wall with ecchymosis. She noted 
that it was somewhat similar to lesions she has developed 
previously, although larger. On exam this seemed more firm and 
discrete than a typical  rectus sheath hematoma, so ultrasound 
was obtained. The appearance was most consistent with a 
thrombosed varicosity, although hematoma could not be ruled out. 
Because the patient wished to be discharged this could not be 
monitored for interval progression, although given the firm 
discrete nature, it seemed that if it was a hematoma it was 
likely contained and tamponaded. Gave instructions to patient to 
watch closely and have low threshold to seek further care should 
this worsen or additional lesions develop. Patient preferred to 
accept this risk rather than remain in the hospital. 

#Acute on chronic anemia
Patient with known anemia of renal failure/inflammation and 
already on Epo as an outpatient. Increased epo resistance is a 
possible cause. Also worsening myeloma potential cease. GI 
losses unlikely given negative guaiac x3. Normal bilirubin not
suggestive of destruction. She appropriately responded to 
transfusion. No evidence of iron deficiency or megaloblastic 
anemia. Has hem follow-up in 2 days and will have labs at that 
time.

#HTN
Mild-moderate persistent HTN despite amlodipine, which shoudl be 
addressed further as an outpatient. 

#Hypothyroidism (history of Graves)
Her TSH has been relatively suppressed on current regimen. 
Raised issue of potentially lowering dose with her PCP in case 
this make her less prone to afib. 

#IgG Lambda Myeloma and Secondary Amyloidosis (s/p auto 
transplant ___, on Daratumumab)
- held Daratumumab per ___ team

#ESRD (on PD)
#Secondary Hyperparathyroidism
Continued on PD, with renal consult, while inpatient. 

#Circumstances of discharge:
The patient was frustrated with being in the hospital for what 
seemed to be uncertain benefit of bridging to coumadin. This was 
compounded by poor sleep, noisy roommate, and being on ___ 
campus, where getting her peritoneal dialysis was tedious. While 
continuing bridging and monitoring her possible hematoma were 
recommended, these were not felt to be clear contraindications 
to discharge, and given her and her husband's understanding of 
the issues/risks and close follow-up, it was not felt that the 
discharge needed to occur against medical advice. 

=======================

- monitoring anemia, transfusing as needed, further diagnostics 
as appropriate
- consider need for metoprolol as rate control agent. can 
consider discontinuation if no further afib
- establishment with ___ clinic at ___ this week
- can consider whether or not to consider coumadin. will depend

Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital due to anemia and a fast heart 
rate due to atrial fibrillation. We did not identify a clear 
reversible cause of the atrial fibrillation, although your 
anemia likely was a factor. You were started on Coumadin, a 
blood thinner used to reduce the risk of strokes in patients 
with atrial fibrillation. You also developed an area on your 
abdominal wall of unclear nature, but potentially a small blood 
clot or a collection of blood. While on Coumadin you are at 
increased risk of dangerous bleeding, so if you have any 
significant injuries (e.g. hitting your head) or notice new 
bleeding (e.g. red or black stool) you need to seek care right 
away. 

Plans after discharge:
- you should have labs checked in 2 days when you come back to 
___, including blood counts and your INR
- you should return to care if there is any enlargement of the 
bump on your abdomen or other bumps, or if you are having other 
new symptoms
- you can take Coumadin 5 mg daily for now. you should be 
contacted by the ___ clinic tomorrow to schedule follow-up 
in their clinic
- continue discussing with your outpatient providers whether or 
not to continue Coumadin
- continue addressing your anemia and high blood pressure with 
your outpatient providers

Brief Hospital Course:
This is an ___ year old woman who had a fall and developed right 
SHOULDER DISLOCATION which was reduced by the ED physician and 
placement was confirmed with several shoulder X-Rays. She was 
treated with standing Tylenol, prn oxycodone 2.5 mg, and ___. She 
had a sling placement. The sling should remain in place for 
several weeks as she most likely had rotator cuff tear 
associated with her dislocation (case and images were discussed 
with orthopaedics). ___ cuff tear is a very common 
complication of shoulder dislocation in the elderly (per 
orthopaedic). She should see outpatient shoulder specialist in 
few weeks after discharge and appointment could not be scheduled 
because of discharge to rehab. She was admitted because of 
HYPOXIA in the ED. She had no H/O COPD, asthma, or significant 
smoking history. She had a history of angina but no heart 
failure (no cath but on medical treatment with Imdur). She had 
DOE for several weeks without explanation or diagnosis. She had 
a history of OSA treated with CPAP. Her CXR was normal except 
for hyperinflation. There was no pneumonia. Her most recent 
Echocardiogram (___) showed diastolic dysfunction. She 
underwent CTA of the chest, repeat Echocardiogram, and BNP. The 
CT showed no pulmonary embolism or significant interstitial 
pulmonary disease. However it showed bronchiectasis and evidence 
of prior lung infection. The ECHO and BNP were both suggestive 
of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy from long standing hypertension 
chronic diastolic heart failure. The Echo also suggested 
moderate aortic regurgitation. The hypoxia was also related to 
atelectasis from sedation required to reduce shoulder. She 
stated she was "passed out" from the morphine in the ER. She was 
treated with incentive spirometry, ambulation tid, and we 
finally added Lasix (instead of HCTZ). We also increased her BP 
medications (the atenolol and the Imdur for better BP control). 
We were able to wean O2. There was a question of URINARY TRACT 
INFECTION. Her UA was only positive for ___ WBC, nitrate, and 
few bacteria. She had no urinary symptoms initially but then 
developed urgency and was treated empirically with Bactrim. She 
was discharged to short term rehab (less than 30 days) for her 
inability to care for herself with shoulder pain and limited ROM 
and ankle sprain as she lives alone. 

The new diagnosis are :

Diastolic heart failure from hypertrophic cardiomyopathy from 
chronic hypertension. 
Aortic regurgitation 
Bronchiectasis

She was asked to follow up with Cardiology and orthopaedic.  All 
of the above was discussed with her 2 daughters. ___ time 
more than 30 minutes.

___ ___ percutaneous nephrostomy tube report:
ANESTHESIA: Moderate sedation was provided by administering 
divided doses of fentanyl (100 mcg) and Versed (2 mg) throughout 
the total intraservice time of 35 minutes, during which the 
patient's hemodynamic parameters were 
continuously monitored.   
PROCEDURE: Bilateral percutaneous nephrostomy tube placement. 
FINDINGS: After the risks and benefits of the procedure were 
explained to the patient, written informed consent was obtained. 
The patient was placed prone on the table and her bilateral 
flanks were prepped and draped in standard sterile fashion. A 
pre-procedure timeout was performed. 
LEFT: Under ultrasound and fluoroscopic guidance, a left lower 
pole posterior calix was cannulated with a 21-gauge Cook needle 
through which a 0.018 wire was advanced into the renal pelvis. 
The needle was exchanged for AccuStick sheath. The wire was 
removed. Clear urine drained from the catheter. The wire, inner 
dilator and metallic shaft of the AccuStick sheath were removed, 
and a Amplatz wire was advanced into the renal pelvis. An 8 
___ dilator was used to open the tract over the Amplatz wire. 
This was followed by successful placement of the 8 ___ 
nephrostomy tube with pigtail locked within the renal pelvis of 
the left kidney. Contrast was injected confirming this location. 
The catheter was secured to the skin with 0 silk suture and 
StatLock. The catheter was placed to external bag drainage. 
RIGHT: Under ultrasound and fluoroscopic guidance, a right lower 
pole posterior calix was cannulated with a 21-gauge Cook needle 
through which a 0.018 wire was advanced into the renal pelvis. 
The needle was exchanged for AccuStick sheath. The wire was 
removed. Clear urine drained from the catheter. The wire, inner 
dilator and metallic shaft of the AccuStick sheath were removed, 
and a Amplatz wire was advanced into the renal pelvis. An 8 
___ dilator was used to open the tract over the Amplatz wire. 
This was followed by successful placement of the 8 ___ 
nephrostomy tube with pigtail locked within the renal pelvis of 
the right kidney. Contrast was injected confirming this 
location. The catheter was secured to the skin with 0 silk 
suture and StatLock. The catheter was placed to external bag 
drainage.
FINDINGS: Moderate bilateral hydronephrosis/hydroureter. 
Obstruction of the bilateral distal third of the ureters 
(complete obstruction on the right, minimal contrast passage 
into bladder on the left). 
There were no immediate complications. 
IMPRESSION: Successful bilateral percutaneous nephrostomies with 
8 ___ 
nephrostomy tubes. 

___ Pelvic MRI without contrast: 
COMPARISON: Outside hospital CT abdomen ___. 
FINDINGS: 
The uterus and cervix are both enlarged and both are markedly 
abnormal in appearance. The cervix has been replaced by 
heterogeneously T2 hyperintense tissue which invades into the 
posterior vaginal fornix (4:24). This measures approximately 9.3 
x 8.6 cm in the axial plane and up to 18 cm in craniocaudal 
dimension. In addition, there is extension into the parametrial 
tissues diffusely (3:21). Several discrete nodules appear 
relatively more T2 hyperintense including several nodules which 
have passed through the mesorectal fascia and are within the 
mesorectal fat (3:21). In addition, there is a small amount of 
tumor which appears to have invaded through the sigmoid wall 
(3:15). An additional nodule displaces the bladder anteriorly, 
although no frank invasion to the bladder wall can be 
appreciated (4:20). The uterus itself is also markedly abnormal 
and based on the T2 and diffusion signal characteristics, there 
is likely frank invasion of the tumor throughout the uterus. 
There is also a 5.9 x 4.7 cm fundal fibroid (3:6). The tumor 
within the uterine body appears to be confined to the uterus. 
  
There is 3.1 x 2.6 cm mass along the left pelvic side wall 
(3:14), identical in signal intensity to the cervical tumor, 
consistent with a lymph node deposit as the small left ovary 
appears adjacent. The left ovary could not well defined on this 
study though is likely between a dilated right tube and fibroid. 
There is a tubular T2 hyperintense structure in the right 
adnexal region measuring approximately 7.1 x 3.5 cm. This 
contains T2 hypointense debris in a dependent distribution. 
Given this appearance, it is most likely reflecting a dilated 
fallopian tube. The urinary bladder and rectum are unremarkable 
in appearance, although as stated before, there are tumor 
deposits extending into the mesorectal fat. 
  
Additional limited in- and out-of-phase T1-weighted images were 
obtained of the upper abdomen to assess the left adrenal mass. 
This mass measures approximately 3.5 x 3 cm and demonstrates 
diffuse loss of signal on out-of-phase compared to in-phase 
T1-weighted images, consistent with an adenoma. The visualized 
osseous structures are unremarkable.   
  
IMPRESSION: 
1. Large cervical mass, replacing both the cervix and uterus 
extending into the parametrium, mesorectal fat and likely the 
sigmoid colon focally.  Overall, this mass measures greater than 
18 cm in craniocaudal extent. MRI stage T4 given invasion of the 
sigmoid colon. 
2. Enlarged abnormal lymph node in the left hemipelvis. 
3. Dilated cystic structure in the right adnexa likely 
hydrosalpinx with debris. 
4. Left adrenal adenoma.

___ PET-CT
HEAD/NECK: There is a 7 mm hypoattenuating non FDG avid left 
thyroid lobe nodule. There are no suspicious FDG avid lesions.  
CHEST: There is a non FDG avid 1 cm nodule in the right major 
fissure of the lungs. There are no suspicious FDG avid lesions. 
There is a small pericardial effusion.  
ABDOMEN/PELVIS: Stable left adrenal gland adenoma (non FDG avid 
- SUV 2.2). Redemonstrated is the large about 9.5 x 8.5 cm 
cervical mass with a SUVmax of about 15, with invasion of the 
sigmoid colon and mesorectum (as seen on the previous MRI), with 
a large left 3.1 x 2.5 cm FDG avid external iliac lymph node 
with a SUV max of 14.7 (imag 147). There is a non FDG avid right 
hydrosalpinx.  
MUSCULOSKELETAL: There are no suspicious FDG avid lesions.  
Physiologic uptake is seen in the brain, myocardium, salivary 
glands, GI and GU tracts, liver and spleen. 
IMPRESSION: 1. Large FDG avid cervical mass and pelvic 
lymphadenopathy. 2. 1 cm pulmonary nodule in the right major 
fissure, likely represents benign lymph node. However, attention 
on follow-up studies is recommended. 3. No suspicious FDG avid 
lesions to suggest distant metastatic disease. 

___ Cervical mass biopsy and left vulvar biopsy pathology 
report
I.  Cervix, biopsy (A):
- Squamous cell carcinoma, invasive, moderately differentiated.
- Depth of invasion cannot be assessed.
II.  Vulva, biopsy (B):
High grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (Vulvar 
Intraepithelial Neoplasia 3).
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ G7P2 woman with poor medical compliance who 
presented to ___ with two weeks of nausea, vomiting, 
malaise and abdominal pain and was found to have a large pelvic 
mass on CT and ___. She was transferred to ___ where she was 
admitted to the ICU after bilateral nephrostomy tube placement 
by interventional radiology and then transferred to the 
gynecologic oncology service for work-up of her pelvic mass when 
she was medically stabilized. Her hospital course, by problem, 
was as follows:
.
#Acute Kidney Injury:  Based on imaging showing bilateral 
hydronephrosis and hydroureters, the etiology of her ___ was 
largely post-renal from obstruction.  The most important 
intervention was placement of bilateral nephrostomy tubes.  She 
quickly had nearly 2 liters of clear urine output after 
placement of nephrostomy tubes. She did not have any urgent 
indication for dialysis and therefore her electrolytes were 
monitored closely q6h for 48 hours with appropriate decrease in 
her potassium and phos. Her creatinine decreased from 18.5 on 
admission to 2.1 on discharge. She received teaching for care of 
her percutaneous nephrostomy tubes prior to discharge, and will 
follow-up with nephrology and urology at ___.
.
#Hyponatremia: Likely hypovolemic in etiology from decreased 
oral intake and emesis prior to admission.  She was given 1L NS 
boluses x 2 and sodium was monitored q6h for development of 
post-diuresis hypernatremia. She was maintained on D5W with 
bicarb to prevent a rapid increase in serum sodium greater than 
10 in 24 hours, according to nephrology recommendations. Her Na 
on admission was 127, and normalized on the afternoon of 
hospital day 2 at which point she was maintained of D5W until 
she was taking PO, at which point she was saline locked.
.
# Cervical mass: CT scan at ___ showed a large mass arising 
from cervix, bilateral moderate hydronephrosis, and a possible 
1cm R lung density. After she was medically stabilized in the 
ICU, she was transferred to the gynecologic oncology service on 
hospital day 1. On hospital day 2, she was taken to the OR for 
an exam under anesthesia, cervical mass biopsy, left posterior 
vulvar biopsy, cystoscopy, and proctoscopy. Intraoperative 
findings were notable for a large cervical mass extending down 
the vagina with parametrial involvement from the sidewall. There 
was no evidence of invasion of the bladder or rectal mucosa. 
Please refer to Dr. ___ report for details of the 
operation. Final pathology is pending at the time of this 
discharge summary. A pelvic MRI confirmed the 18cm cervical mass 
extending in to the parametrium, mesorectal fat, and likely the 
sigmoid colon with enlarged lymph nodes in the left pelvis. A 
PET-CT was performed to evaluate for distant metastasis showed 
"no suspicious FDG avid lesions to suggest distant metastatic 
disease". Her post-operative course was uncomplicated. Her diet 
was advanced on post-operative day 1 with no nausea, pain was 
controlled with percocet, she had good urine output from both 
nephrostomy tubes, and she was ambulating independently without 
difficulty.
.
#Anemia: Unclear baseline Hct for pt, Hct of 25.8 in ED. She was 
hemodynamically stable, without evidence of active hemorrhage. 
Prior to going to the OR on hospital day 2, her HCT decreased to 
23, so she was transfused 2 units pRBCs for stabilization prior 
to cervical biopsy. Her post-transfusion HCT was appropriate at 
32.5. Post-operatively, her cervical bleeding was minimal, and 
her HCT on discharge was stable at 31.
.
#Leukocytosis:  She presented with a leukocytosis of 20.2.  
Differential included complicated urinary tract infection vs. 
malignancy/stress reaction. She received 2 doses of ceftriaxone, 
which was discontinued after urine culture was negative. Blood 
culture were no growth at the time of this discharge summary.
.
#Anion gap metabolic acidosis:  Most likely ___ ___ and uremia, 
lactate normal at 1.1.  VBG on admission revealed a pH of 7.31.
.
#Code status: Patient was okay with intubation but was DNR
.
#Soc: She was seen by social work for her new diagnosis, coping, 
and resources.

By hospital day 4/post-operative day 2, her creatinine was 
significantly improved, and her electrolytes were normalized. 
She was tolerating a regular diet, ambulating independently, and 
pain was controlled with percocet. She was then discharged home 
in stable condition with plans for outpatient follow-up with 
___ urology, ___ Kidney and Hypertension, ___ 
radiation oncology, and Dr. ___.

Discharge Instructions:
Ms. ___,

You were admitted to the ICU and then transferred to the 
gynecologic oncology service for a cervical mass that was 
blocking both ureters. You had percutaneous nephrostomy tubes 
placed to drain your kidneys, and your kidney function test has 
improved. We biopsied the cervical mass, and the final pathology 
is pending at this time. A pelvic MRI confirmed the large mass 
in your pelvis, and PET-CT was performed but the result is not 
finalized yet. Please follow these instructions:

General instructions:  
* Take your medications as prescribed.  
* Do not drive while taking narcotics.  
* Do not combine narcotic and sedative medications or alcohol  
* Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs  
* Nothing in the vagina (no tampons, no douching, no sex), no 
heavy lifting of objects >10lbs for 6 weeks.  
* You may eat a regular diet  
* Percutaneous nephrostomy tube care as instructed

Ms. ___ is a ___ with cirrhosis due to NASH and

to be discharged to rehab.

placed/bridled on ___, and subsequently advanced post-pyloric

Although pt's abdomen appears distended, multiple bedside 
ultrasounds showed no tappable ascites. She did not receive

around the liver, patent TIPS, and cholelithiasis. She was 
continued on home lactulose, rifaximin. We continued to hold

holding diuretics (notably did have crackles on lungs however 
had normal oxygen saturations on room air, did not have BLE 
edema or ascites). Given her recurrent ___ to diuretics, will 
plan to allow patient to auto-diurese now that her kidney 
function has improved with further consideration for starting 
diuretics at outpatient Hepatology follow up. She was otherwise 
continued on home lactulose, rifaximin.

Dear Ms. ___,

WHAT HAPPENED WHILE YOU WERE IN THE HOSPITAL?  
 - We placed a feeding tube for nutrition.

WHAT DO YOU NEED TO DO WHEN YOU LEAVE THE HOSPITAL?  
 - Work with physical therapy at rehab to gain your strength so 
that you can get a liver transplant
 - You must never drink alcohol again or you could die.  
 - Take all of your medications as prescribed (listed below)

medications. Call your doctor if your weight changes by more 
than 3 pounds

call your primary care doctor or come to the emergency 
department immediately.  

It was a pleasure participating in your care. We wish you the 
best!

pancreas transplant (___) now on PD, HTN, CAD (s/p DES to LCx 
on DAPT in ___, PVD s/p b/l BKA presents complaining of nausea 
and vomiting. Symptoms have been ongoing for the past 5 days. 
Patient unsure what caused this acute illness. Endorses mild 
diffuse abdominal pain, SOB that began around the same time that 
the n/v began. Denies f/c, diarrhea, CP. No blood in vomit. He 
states that he has been unable to keep any of his medicines 
down, but that he has been getting his peritoneal dialysis 
nightly. He also states that he has been taking all of his 
insulin as prescribed, even when he slowed down PO intake with 
n/v. No recent sick contacts, recent travels, recent illnesses 
or antibiotics. 

In ED initial VS: T 98, P 78, BP 204/115, R 28, 99% RA. HR 
increased into 100s in ED. By time of transfer to the ICU, BP 
and HR had normalized.

initiation of insulin gtt. WBC 9.9. BUN 45, Cr 10.4. Trop 1.47, 
downtrended to 1.31 on repeat check, MB 4. LFTs unremarkable. 
VBG 7.39/42. 
 
Patient was given: insulin gtt at 7U/hr, IVF 1L NS, clopidogrel 
75mg, carvedilol 37.5mg, atorvastatin 80mg, ASA 324mg, IV 
lorazepam.  

Imaging notable for: CXR w/ small area of atelectasis associated 
w/ small R pleural effusion but otherwise unremarkable. 

Consults: cardiology consulted re: elevated troponin, thought 
EKG to be consistent w/ LVH w/ strain and unchanged from priors, 
stated that troponin elevated I/s/o dialysis.  

On arrival to the MICU, patient endorses feeling better than 
when he first presented. Denies current n/v, asking to eat. No 
current CP or SOB. Denies f/c at home.

Echo ___:
Conclusions
 The left atrium is mildly dilated. There is mild symmetric left 
ventricular hypertrophy. The left ventricular cavity size is 
normal. There is mild to moderate global left ventricular 
hypokinesis (LVEF = 40 %). [Intrinsic left ventricular systolic 
function is likely more depressed given the severity of valvular 
regurgitation.] Tissue Doppler imaging suggests an increased 
left ventricular filling pressure (PCWP>18mmHg). Doppler 
parameters are most consistent with Grade II (moderate) left 
ventricular diastolic dysfunction. The right ventricular free 
wall thickness is normal. Right ventricular chamber size is 
normal with borderline normal free wall function. The diameters 
of aorta at the sinus, ascending and arch levels are normal. The 
aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened. There is no 
aortic valve stenosis. The mitral valve leaflets are 
structurally normal. Moderate (2+) mitral regurgitation is seen. 
The pulmonary artery systolic pressure could not be determined.
 Compared with the prior study (images reviewed) of ___, 
the findings are similar.
 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ of T1DM, ESRD s/p failed kidney transplant (___) and 
pancreas transplant (___) now on PD, HTN, CAD (s/p DES to LCx 
on DAPT in ___, PVD s/p b/l BKA who p/w n/v, elevated glucose, 
anion gap metabolic acidosis c/f DKA.

=================  
ACTIVE ISSUES  
=================
# Gap Metabolic Acidosis concerning for DKA: Patient had had 
multiple admissions in the past for DKA and a pattern of 
non-compliance. However, patient stated he had been compliant w/ 
insulin at home. There were no recent illnesses or stresses that 
he reported and no recent alcohol use. Upon review of 
medications with ___ Diabetes specialists, however, patient 
stated that he had only been taking novolog and also 
intraperitoneal insulin (i.e. not taking any long-acting 
insulin). On admission, patient had an anion gap metabolic 
acidosis w/ glucose 341 upon arrival that uptrended to 463 in 
the ED before being placed on insulin gtt. Patient was anuric, 
so urine ketones were not checked. Patient was restarted on SC 
insulin upon arrival to ICU floor w/ end therapy for insulin 
being detemir 4U at breakfast and 6U at bedtime, novolog 5U w/ 
meals, novolog sliding scale w/ meals. He also will receive 18U 
of novolin insulin in his PD fluid. ___ clarified his insulin 
regimen prior to discharge. Patient notably had some abdominal 
pain and nausea the day of discharge, but his laboratory work 
was unremarkable except for mild leukocytosis.  

# Hypertensive emergency, type II NSTEMI: Trop was elevated to 
1.47 upon arrival, downtrended subsequently. Patient had a poor 
baseline of known CAD and is s/p DES to ___ in ___. Has ESRD 
but baseline trops 0.4-0.5. EKGs unchanged from prior. Most 
likely demand ischemia I/s/o hypovolemia ___ DKA and/or 
contribution from hypertensive emergency. Cards saw patient in 
ED and said no intervention or heparin gtt at this time. 
Continued home ASA/Plavix, Lipitor 80 and Coreg. Echo 
demonstrated no marked changes from his prior. 

# HTN Urgency/Emergency: Presented w/ sBP in 200s, improved to 
170s in ED. Had a trop leak as above, thought to be possibly 
demand ischemia ___ to hypertension. By the time he arrived to 
the ICU, his BP had normalized. Patient stated he was not able 
to keep PO meds down at home given n/v, hence the elevated BP 
upon arrival. Patient just had one episode of SBP > 180 on the 
day prior to his discharge, though this improved once he took 
his oral home blood pressure meds.

# Anemia: Patient demonstrated a downtrending Hb from prior 
without evidence of hemolysis or bleeding. He did not require 
transfusion. He stated he was due for his Aranesp infusion, 
which was originally to be ___. His peritoneal dialysis team 
including Dr. ___ was contacted for follow-up. On review of 
his CBCs, it was noted that he has had a long-standing anemia 
with some predominance of myeloid precursors. Hematology 
consultation as outpatient is suggested. 

# Hyponatremia: likely pseudohyponatremia given elevated 
glucose. Resolved w/ tx.

# ESRD on PD: s/p failed kidney and pancreas transplant. Renal 
consulted to continue PD in house. Continued home sevalamir, 
nephrocaps, and prednisone. He noted that after peritoneal 
dialysis he had stomach pain and difficulty taking his home 
meds. His outpatient nephrologist was contacted regarding 
management strategies for this, such as leaving in 100cc to 
prevent pain.

=================  
CHRONIC ISSUES  
================= 
# Anemia: at baseline, monitored
# Depression: Continued home celexa and Wellbutrin 
# GERD: continued home PPI
# Gastroparesis: continued home reglan

Transitional issues: 
- patient notably refused ___ on discharge.
- patient has blood and peritoneal cultures that require 
follow-up.
- Patient is being discharged on an insulin regimen of novolog 5 
units at breakfast, lunch, and dinner, with 4 units of levemir 
at breakfast and 6 units at dinner. He also injects 18 units of 
novolin into 6L 1.5% peritoneal dialysis bag. He was written for 
new supplies.
- Patient had ongoing presence of anemia on discharge, with Hb 
downtrending from 10 to low 7s this admission. Seemed most 
consistent with downtrend in the setting of inflammation, with 
patient being due for his outpatient Aranesp. On review of his 
CBCs, however, it was noted that he has had a long-standing 
anemia with some predominance of myeloid precursors. Hematology 
consultation as outpatient is suggested. Dr. ___ was 
contacted re: setting up outpatient PD team to provide Aranesp. 
- his abdominal pain mostly occurs toward the end of his PD 
sessions; Nephrology may consider leaving residual fluid to 
reduce the discomfort of the final fluid pull of his PD, as 
suggested by inpatient Nephrology consultation
- Patient had slight leukocytosis on discharge labs. He should 
ideally receive follow-up sets of labs including CBC within one 
week.

FINDINGS: There is no acute intracranial hemorrhage, edema,

maintained. Normal cervical lordosis is exaggerated as on the

is 
unremarkable. There is a well-defined descending thoracic aorta. 
The cardiac silhouette is within normal limits for size. No

involving the anterolateral aspect of the right sixth rib 
consistent with interval fracture. Given history, this may be 
acute. It is new since the prior study. The spinal column is 
normal on AP view.

aspect of the right sixth rib. No pneumothorax noted.

FINDINGS: The liver demonstrates a diffusely increased 
echogenicity 
consistent with fatty infiltration. There are no focal liver or 
liver 
abnormalities detected. The main portal vein is patent with 
appropriate 
hepatopetal flow. There is no intra- or extra-hepatic biliary 
dilatation. 
This is a technically limited study, and the pancreas is not 
well visualized. The spleen measures 10.3 cm and is 
unremarkable. The abdominal aorta was unable to be adequately 
visualized. The left kidney measures 9.1 cm and the right kidney 
measures 9.0 cm. There is no evidence of hydronephrosis, 
nephrolithiasis, or discrete masses in the bilateral kidneys. 
There is noted to be a right pleural effusion.   
IMPRESSION: 
1. Diffuse fatty infiltration of the liver. Other forms of liver 
disease and more advanced liver disease including significant 
hepatic fibrosis/cirrhosis cannot be excluded on this study.   
2. Technically limited ultrasound.   
3. Right pleural effusion.   
The study and the report were reviewed by the staff radiologist.

decubitus view demonstrates no evidence of free air.   
IMPRESSION: No evidence of obstruction or free air.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ year old female with a multiple medical 
problems PMH significant for possible seizure disorder admitted 
for a  fall complicated by hypotension and mental status change 
and found to have a UTI.
.
#Fall: Patient found not to have a fracture.  This was not her 
first fall.  It is unclear if this was related to a seizure or 
not.  She will be seen in ___ clinic.  She was seen by 
___ who thought that she was a high fall risk and recommended 
going to a rehab hospital.  Staff agreed with this assessment 
however patient had a bad expereince at a rehab hospital before 
and refused to go despite our recommendation.  Multiple 
conversations were held with her regarding this but she refused 
to go.  We discharged her home with ___ and home ___ three times 
a week.  

# Hypotension: Uncertain etiology at this time.  Hypotension was 
not fluid responsive, but multiple lactate levels have been 
negative.  Unlikely to be infectious/sepsis.  Likely element of 
autonomic dysfunction.  ___ be related to low cortisol although 
unlikely.  

# Change in Mental Status: Change in mental status may be due to 
polypharmacy, post-ictal confusion, primary CNS, and hepatic 
encephalopathy.  Resolved on its own and patient is back to 
baseline of conversive and oriented times three.  Although she 
does seem to lack insight into her multiple diseases.  
Hepatology did not think that there was a liver etiology for her 
issues.  Her hepatitis serologies came back consistent with Hep 
B vaccinated and nothing else.  Her cerruloplasmin was 
boarderline low at 19 and her alpha 1 antitrypsan was normal.  
It is unclear if she has some unifying diagnosis to explain her 
liver abnormalities, hypothyroidism and seizures.  She did have 
elevated ferritin and some evidence of pituitary dysfunction.  
In future may consider further workup for hemachromatosis.  
.
# UTI: Prelim speciation as E.coli sensitive to bactrim.  
Patient given course of Bactrim.  
.
# Anemia: Hct this AM 28.4.  Patient received 1u PRBC with 
appropriate increase.  
.
# Coagulopathy: Likely secondary to liver disease and/or 
malnutrition. Received 10 mg po vitamin K yesterday.  Patient 
started on daily vitamin K.  
.
# Nutritional status: Patient came in with low albumin and found 
to have low albumin.  Nutritional consult obtained and they 
recomended supplementing meals with ensure.  This was done in 
the hospital.  Unlikely patient will continue as an outpatient.  
___ need further nutritional work as outpatient.  
.
# Hypothyroid: Patient with TSH on admission of <0.02 with free 
T4 of 1.5.  T3 found to be low.  Would re-check as outpatient 
when she is in a more stable setting and adjust dose at that 
time.  
.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ woman admitted with anorexia nervosa and severe
protein-calorie malnutrition. 

#Anorexia nervosa: 
#Moderate protein-calorie malnutrition. 
   Her weight is less than 75% ideal body weight. She was 
orthostatic and hypokalemic on admission, but this has resolved 
with minimal repletion of electrolytes. Phosphorous has been 
totally stable after four days of adequate feedings and 
prophylactic oral supplementation. She was also given 
multivitamin with minerals. 
   She took meals on our eating disorder protocol. She had been 
doing well at first, and ate 100% of her first 8 meals. At the 
end of her hospitalization, she left half a meal, citing 
abdominal pain. Her excuse for failing was quite rational, but 
the nature of our protocol is to accept no excuses. Therefore, 
the recommendation was made to start feeds by NG tube until she 
can re-demonstrate perfect adherence to voluntary feeds. She did 
not assent to this, and it was not clear whether her legal 
guardian had the authority to consent on her behalf for NG tube 
(he suspected he did not have this authority, but our hospital 
lawyer advised us that it is implicit in his guardianship per 
recent case law). She received a bed at ___ prior to 
resolution of this impasse. 
 
#Constipation, abdominal pain: 
  A chronic, ongoing issue. She takes Miralax TID and Colace BID 
at home, although unclear how much of this is appropriate 
treatment of constipation and how much is part of her disorder

Brief Hospital Course:
Mrs. ___ was admitted to the hospital and taken to the 
Operating Room where she underwent a video-assisted 
thoracoscopic surgery (VATS) right upper
lobectomy, video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS) right 
lower lobe superior segmentectomy, mediastinal lymph node 
dissection and bronchoscopy with lavage. She tolerated the 
procedure well and returned to the PACU in stable condition.  
She maintained stable hemodynamics and her pain was controlled 
with IV Dilaudid. She had no air leak from her chest tube and 
minimal drainage.

Following transfer to the Surgical floor she had some oxygen 
desaturations along with dyspnea and more crepitus over her 
right chest.  Her chest xray showed a slightly larger right 
apical space and her tube was placed on suction with resolution 
of her symptoms. Her pain was controlled with Oxycodone and she 
was able to use her incentive spirometer effectively.  Following 
removal of her chest tube she has a stable right apical space 
but eventually developed a large air fluid level and a pigtail 
catheter was placed on ___.  Subsequently a chest CT was 
done which demonstrated RLL atelectesis with obstruction of the 
RLL bronchus.  After vigorous pulmonary toilet including chest 
___ and increased incentive spirometry, her CXR improved.  On 
___ she underwent a bronchoscopy to assure airway patency 
and had a large mucous plug removed.  The BAL grew Pseudomonas 
and she was placed on a 7 day course of Levaquin as she also had 
some GPC in the initial gram stain.  Her WBC was 13K  but she ws 
afebrile. Her pigtail catheter was removed on ___ after a 
successful clamp trial.  Her surgical sites were healing well.

Following removal of her foley catheter she had some urinary 
retention and was straight cathed for 800 cc's but had no 
trouble thereafter.  Her appetite was modest and she was 
encouraged to take additional protein supplements.

She will need to follow up in the Thoracic Clinic in ___ weeks 
and will also follow up with the Medical Oncologist at the same 
time.

Discharge Instructions:
* You were admitted to the hospital for lung surgery and 
required a longer stay as your lung collapsed, requiring 
replacement of a chest tube along with brochoscopy. You are now 
ready for discharge.
* Continue to use your incentive spirometer 10 times an hour 
while awake.
* Check your incisions daily and report any increased redness or 
drainage.   Cover the area with a gauze pad if it is draining.
* Your chest tube dressing may be removed in 48 hours.  If it 
starts to drain, cover it with a clean dry dressing and change 
it  as needed to keep site clean and dry.
* You will continue to need pain medication once you are home 
but you can wean it over a few weeks as the discomfort resolves. 
 Make sure that you have regular bowel movements while on 
narcotic pain medications as they are constipating which can 
cause more problems.  Use a stool softener or gentle laxative to 
stay regular.
* Continue your antibiotic until the prescription is completed.
* No driving while taking narcotic pain medication.
* Take Tylenol  ___ mg every 6 hours in between your narcotic.  
* Continue to stay well hydrated and eat well to heal your 
incisions
* Shower daily. Wash incision with mild soap & water, rinse, pat 
dry
* No tub bathing, swimming or hot tubs until incision healed
* No lotions or creams to incision site
* Walk ___ times a day and gradually increase your activity as 
you can tolerate.

Call Dr. ___ ___ if you experience:
-Fevers > 101 or chills
-Increased shortness of breath, chest pain or any other symptoms 
that concern you.

and oral medications by POD#1. The patient was given

Discharge Instructions:
Discharge Instructions:

INSTRUCTIONS AFTER ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY:

- You were in the hospital for orthopedic surgery. It is normal 
to feel tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling 
should improve over the first few days to week. 
- Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow 
your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times.

ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
- WBAT RLE

MEDICATIONS:
- Please take all medications as prescribed by your physicians 
at discharge.
- Continue all home medications unless specifically instructed 
to stop by your surgeon.
- Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate 
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
- Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you should 
drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and take a stool softener 
(colace) to prevent this side effect.

ANTICOAGULATION:
- Please take ASA 325 daily for 4 weeks

WOUND CARE:
- You may shower. No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks.
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken 
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.
- Please remain in your dressing and do not change unless it is 
visibly soaked or falling off.

DANGER SIGNS:
Please call your PCP or surgeon's office and/or return to the 
emergency department if you experience any of the following:
- Increasing pain that is not controlled with pain medications
- Increasing redness, swelling, drainage, or other concerning 
changes in your incision
- Persistent or increasing numbness, tingling, or loss of 
sensation
- Fever > 101.4
- Shaking chills
- Chest pain
- Shortness of breath
- Nausea or vomiting with an inability to keep food, liquid, 
medications down
- Any other medical concerns

Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo M with HCV, EtOH cirrhosis complicated by encephalopathy 
and ascites, on liver transplant list (MELD 18), and history of 
pulmonary embolism s/p anticoagulation, who presents with 
vomiting x 2 days and dizziness.  
.  
#. Vomiting: The etiology of the patient's vomiting was unclear, 
but was likely related to viral infection. It was non-bloody. 
There was no further vomiting after admission. Blood and urine 
cultures were negative. CXR showed no evidence of pneumonia. 
Diagnostic paracentesis was negative for spontaneous bacterial 
peritonitis. The patient did have several insect bites, so he 
was started on empiric doxycycline (planned 7-day course). He 
was also treated empirically with ciprofloxacin (planned 7-day 
course).
.
#. Dehydration: The patient became dehydrated in the setting of 
overdiuresis and vomiting. He was treated with 1 L of normal 
saline and 100 grams of albumin. Diuretics were initially held 
but were restarted at a lower dose prior to discharge. The 
patient was instructed to monitor his weight daily and report 
any change to his doctor. He was also instructed to hold his 
diuretics if he developed vomiting.
.
#. Acute on chronic renal failure: The patient presented with 
creatinine 1.8, up from baseline 1.3. The etiology was thought 
to be prerenal, related to diuresis and vomiting. The patient 
was treated with 1 L of normal saline and 100 grams of albumin. 
Diuretics initially held then restarted at a lower dose. The 
patient's creatinine trended down and was 1.3 at the time of 
discharge.
.
#. Hepatic encephalopathy: The patient developed worsened 
hepatic encephalopathy in the setting of dehydration. This 
improved with lactulose. At the time of discharge, the patient's 
mental status had returned to baseline. 
.
#. Headache: The patient had a headache throughout his 
admission. There was no nuchal rigidity. CT head ___ was 
normal. The headaches improved with low-dose acetaminophen (<2 
grams/day).
.
#. Hepatitis C Cirrhosis: Continued lactulose and rifaximin. 
Held and then restarted diuretics as above. An ultrasound of the 
abdomen was performed prior to discharge and did not show enough 
ascites to drain.
.
#. Microcytic Anemia. Baseline Hct around 30. Iron studies in 
___ suggestive of iron deficiency. The patient will 
need an outpatient colonoscopy if he has not had one.
.  
#. Thrombocytopenia: Baseline around 60-70. On admission, the 
patient's platelet count was near the patient's baseline. At the 
time of discharge, the patient's platelet count was slightly 
below his baseline. The patient's thrombocytopenia was thought 
to be related to his liver disease.
.
#. Sinus tachycardia: The patient remained tachycardic to 100 to 
110 throughout his admission. The etiology of this was unclear. 
The patient remained hemodynamically stable.
.  
#. Chronic back pain: Continued lidocaine patch.
.  
#. Code status: FULL (confirmed)  
.
#. Contact: Wife - ___ ___ (home) ___ (cell)

You were admitted to the hospital with vomiting and dehydration. 
You may have had an infection, so you were started on 
antibiotics. You had some strain on your kidneys so your 
diuretic medications were adjusted. You were also confused, due

.

atelectasis, but as the left-sided diaphragm is well described, 
significant pleural effusion and parenchymal infiltrate in this 
area is most unlikely. No pneumothorax has developed. Pulmonary 
vasculature is not congested. 
IMPRESSION: Improvement of previously identified left lower lobe 
atelectasis in patient with suspected overdose and previous 
respiratory failure. 

EMG ___:
IMPRESSION: 
Complex, abnormal study. The electrophysiologic findings can be 
explained most parsimoniously by a severe, subacute (between 3 
weeks to 3 months) C7-T1 polyradiculopathy on the right. The 
findings cannot be explained by a 
posterior interosseous neuropathy in isolation. The preservation 
of the medial antebrachial cutaneous response on the right makes 
a brachial plexopathy effecting the lower trunk unlikely. There 
is also evidence for an underlying, mild, chronic C5-7 
radiculopathy on the right. Of note, axonal continuity is 
maintained to all muscles tested. If clinically indicated, 
repeat testing in three months may be warranted. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo M found down at home, intubated in ED for unresponsiveness 
after coumadin and lamictal overdose
.  
# Unresponsiveness /Fall: In the ED, vital signs were initially 
were 99 146/89 HR 86 RR 16 100% The patient was intubated. He 
had CT Head which showed right frontal lobe area concerning for 
a subdural hematoma. Neurosurgery felt that the CT head changes 
were related to post surgical status, and no acute intervention 
was needed. CT Torso showed LLL infiltrate concerning for 
aspiratin pneumonia; thus pt given Vanc/zosyn. Xray of right 
foot done for swelling noted on exam which was negative for 
fracture. Labs remarkable for ABG 7.40/44/324, INR 1.7, lactate 
2.4, WBC 12.4, trop <0.01, creatinine 0.8. EKG with TWI and ST 
depression v4-v6 that resolved on repeat.  The patient was 
admitted to the MICU where the intitial differential also 
included lamictal and coumadin overdose, seizure vs ETOH 
Withdrawal vs arrhythmia (given the EKG changes noted in ED that 
later resolved) vs PE (the patient was subtherapeutic on 
coumadin on arrival) vs Wernickes encephalopathy. 

On arrival to the MICU he was responding to commands with 
lightened sedation but with clonus and hyperreflexia (not 
thought to be new but possibly be more pronounced than 
previously described on OMR notes).  While he was being examined 
by the MICU team off propofol, he started having rhythmic jerky 
movements in all limbs, and neuro was called for concerns of 
seizures. They noted that the patient was able to stop the 
movement for few secs if instructed and was able to follow 
commands during these movements. It was thought that the patient 
was exhibiting clonus due to toxic metabolic encephalopathy due 
to multi medication overdose (lamictal and coumadin) or 
withdrawal (alcohol vs benzodiazepines).  
.  
When the patient was awake to be able to give a history it was 
determined that the patient has a history of alcohol abuse with 
DTs in the past. However, he stated he has not had alcohol in 
over a month. The patien's sister corroborated this story 
telling the neurology team that the patient was in a supervised 
setting post op in his father's home with sister's assistance 
and no alcohol available. She did, however, think that he used 
his anti-anxiety and narcotics Rx at an "accelerated rate" and 
overdosed in part due to despondence over pain/restrictive 
environment. He is normally prescribed 1.5 mg ativan a day.  In 
light of this information, it was thought that the patient might 
be exhibiting withdrawal not from alcohol but from 
benzodiazepines so he was started on a CIWA scale with valium. 
His mental status improved considerably with this regimen.  
  
The patient was also evaluated by psychiatry who did not elicit 
suicidal ideation. The patient told the team that he took ___ 
pills of Warfarin w/Lamotrigine because he "wanted to go to 
sleep." However, in talking with the patient's father, he stated 
that he feels that his son is not safe to go home and may 
actually be a danger to himself. Therefore, psych determined 
that the patient should be ___ with a 1:1 sitter.  

The pateint was deemed stable for the medicine floor and was 
transferred.  There he continued to improve, with no 
disorientation.  He was alert with good concentration.  He was 
maintained on CIWA scale but only required 2 doses of diazepam 
for anxiety.  He did not score above 10 on the CIWA scale.  He 
was maintained on telemetry and had a few episodes of 
tachycardia to the 150s which was thought to be normal sinus 
rhythm.  Because this only happened when he was getting up from 
bed and walking it was thought that he was orthostatic and 
deconditioned from lying in bed for so long.  He was hydrated 
with IV fluids and orthostatics were checked and were negative.  
He was encouraged to walk around 3 times a day each day.

# Suicide attempt:  As stated above the patient denied suicide 
attempt with the overdose, but rather states he was just trying 
to make himself go to sleep by taking all of the medications.  
He was evaluated by psych who also talked to the patient's 
father who thought  the patient would be a danger to himself at 
home.  For this reason and the fact that the patient has prior 
suicide attempts he was made ___ and kept a 1:1 sitter.  
His fluoxetine was restarted at 60 mg a day on ___ but no 
other psychiatric medications were restarted.  TSH was checked 
and was normal at 3.1.  The patient was discharged to an 
___ facility.  
.  
# Subderual hematoma/hygroma: The patient has a chronic right 
frontal hygroma and was evaluated by neurosurgery who felt that 
this was resolving and no intervention was needed.  They also 
felt that there was no contraindication to coumadin. Per 
neurosurgery, the patient will need a follow-up head CT as an 
outpatient in 4 weeks (end of ___.  He should call  
___ to book this appointment.  He 
should follow up with neurosurgery after he gets this CT.  He 
can call the following number to schedule this appointment: 
___.
.  
# Pulmonary infiltrate: CT chest showed evidence of aspiration 
PNA. The patient was afebrile but initially had a mild 
leukocytosis so he was given vanc/Zosyn for 3 days.  Antibiotics 
were stopped because the patient was not exhibiting symptoms and 
was afebrile.  He continued to not have any symptoms of 
pneumonia including shortness of breath, cough, chest pain, or 
fever.
.  
# DVT's: The patient had bilateral lower extremity DVTs 
diagnosed at a recent admission, for which he was discharged on 
coumdain.  After his overdose on coumadin he was given 10 mg IV 
vitamin K at the OSH.  During this hospitalization his initial 
INR was 1.7 so his coumadin was held.  His INR trended down to 
1.0.  Neurosurgery felt that it was ok to restart his coumadin 
so the patient was bridged with lovenox BID.   His INR remained 
at 1.0 for several days so his coumadin dose was increased to 10 
mg for two days before titrating back to 4 mg a day.  The day of 
discharge his INR was 1.4. The patient should continue to get 4 
mg (his home dose) coumadin and have his INR checked every day 
until he is theraputic (INR ___.  At that time he can 
discontinue the lovenox injections.
.
# right hand palsy:  The patient was noted to have a right hand 
palsy where he was unable to extend his right fingers.  It was 
recommenced by Dr. ___ neurosurgeon, that he get an EMG 
study.  The findings of this study were: "Complex, abnormal 
study. The electrophysiologic findings can be explained most 
parsimoniously by a severe, subacute (between 3 weeks to 3 
months) C7-T1 
polyradiculopathy on the right. The findings cannot be explained 
by a 
posterior interosseous neuropathy in isolation."  Neurology 
recommended that the patient follow up with Dr. ___ 
___. and have a repeat EMG in three months.  The patient can call 
___ to schedule the follow up appointment and ___ to schedule the EMG study.  The patient was evaluated 
by Occupational Therapy who priovided a daytime and a nighttime 
splint which he should continue to wear.  The patient noted 
subjective improvement of his wrist extension, but no 
improvement of his finger extension the day of discharge.

bilateral DVTs

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent

 
Discharge Instructions:
You came to the hospital after you were found down on the 
ground.  You told us that you overdosed on Lamictal and 
Coumadin.  You were intubated and monitored in the intensive 
care unit.  We gave you medicines to treat you for 
benzodiazepine withdrawal and supportive measures until the 
medications you overdosed on cleared from your system.  You were 
evaluated by the neurosurgeons who thought that your head did 
not have evidence of bleeding.  They would like you to follow up 
with a repeat head CT in 4 weeks and see them in outpatient 
clinic.  You can call to schedule these appointments (see 
below).

You were also evaluated by the psychiatrists who thought that 
you might be in danger of hurting yourself.  They think you 
would benefit from inpatient psychiatric treatment.  Please 
follow their recommendations regarding restarting your 
medications for depression, some of which we have held during 
this hospitalization.

You were also noted to have a right hand paralysis that you 
first noticed after your initial fall back in ___.  You had 
an EMG study performed which showed some abnormailities in the 
nerves in your arm.  The neurologists would like you to follow 
up with them and have a repeat EMG in 3 months.  Please see 
below for the numbers to call to schedule these appointments.  
You were also seen by occupational therapy who stated you should 
wear a resting splint when you sleep as well as a dyamic brace 
during the day when you are doing activities.  

We restarted you back on your blood thinners for your blood clot 
in your legs.  You should continue to take both the lovenox 
shots twice a day as well as the coumadin once a day and have 
your blood drawn every day until your INR level is theraputic 
(between 2 and 3).  At that time you can stop the lovenox shots 
and just continue with the coumadin.

Pleas note the following changes to your medications:
Please Stop Lamictal
Please Stop Fluoxetine
Please change your oxycodone to 10 mg every 4 hours as needed 
for arm, neck, shoulder pain
Please continue lovenox 60 mg twice a day until your INR is 
between 2 and 3.

Please continue to take the rest of your medications as 
prescribed.

It was a pleasure taking part in your care.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr ___ is a ___ yo man with a history of HTN, HLD, NSTEMI, 
pre-DM and depression who presented with disequlibrium and L leg 
heaviness which resolved by the time of neurologic evaluation. 
Neuro exam was notable for subtle left side clumsiness in upper 
and lower extr and mild left sided dysmetria. MRI is without 
evidence of infarct. CTA head and neck with ~40% stenosis at the 
origin of the left vertebral artery. Given that his exam is 
still subtly abnormal this is most likely an MRI negative 
stroke, cerebellar vs brainstem. Given multiple stroke risk 
factors we will assume this is a stroke. We have increased his 
aspirin to 325mg daily. No other changes were made. He had a 
recent ECHO so this was not repeated. Cause of his stroke may 
have been related to his stenosis of the vertebral artery vs 
small vessel disease.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr ___,
You were hospitalized due to symptoms of disequlibrium and left 
leg heaviness resulting from an ACUTE ISCHEMIC STROKE, a 
condition in which a blood vessel providing oxygen and nutrients 
to the brain is blocked by a clot. The brain is the part of your 
body that controls and directs all the other parts of your body, 
so damage to the brain from being deprived of its blood supply 
can result in a variety of symptoms.

Stroke can have many different causes, so we assessed you for 
medical conditions that might raise your risk of having stroke. 
In order to prevent future strokes, we plan to modify those risk 
factors. Your risk factors are:
pre-diabetes 
high cholesterol 

We are changing your medications as follows:
increasing your aspirin to 325mg daily 

Please take your other medications as prescribed.
Please followup with Neurology and your primary care physician 
as listed below.
If you experience any of the symptoms below, please seek 
emergency medical attention by calling Emergency Medical 
Services (dialing 911). In particular, since stroke can recur, 
please pay attention to the sudden onset and persistence of 
these symptoms:
- sudden partial or complete loss of vision
- sudden loss of the ability to speak words from your mouth
- sudden loss of the ability to understand others speaking to 
you
- sudden weakness of one side of the body
- sudden drooping of one side of the face
- sudden loss of sensation of one side of the body
- sudden difficulty pronouncing words (slurring of speech)
- sudden blurring or doubling of vision
- sudden onset of vertigo (sensation of your environment 
spinning around you)
- sudden clumsiness of the arm and leg on one side or sudden 
tendency to fall to one side (left or right)
- sudden severe headache accompanied by the inability to stay 
awake
It was a pleasure providing you with care during this 
hospitalization.

History of Present Illness:
The patient is a ___ yo woman with medical history of pseudotumor 
cerebri now s/p Diamox treatment followed by Dr. ___ Dr. 
___ in clinic, who presents for evaluation of LOC episodes 
concerning for seizures. 

On the afternoon of her admission day (around 12:30pm), the 
patient reports  sitting on her bed and noting her stomach 
fluttering but denies dizziness as well as visual, olfactory, or 
auditory auras. All of a sudden woke up on the bed
lightheaded and her body felt weak. She endorses tongue biting, 
denies urinary or stool incontinence. It was hard for her to 
stand as she felt generalized weakness but that resolved in 
several hours. Later around 4:30pm she was sitting on her bed 
again and woke up on the floor. She denies hitting her head but 
complains of severe pain on her RT shoulder. She reports later 
in the afternoon had a pressure like headache and decided to 
come to the ED. 

Of note these episodes started a week prior to her admission 
when she woke up on the floor and had injured her head behind he

on both sides. She went to ___ where she had a NCHCT which

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ year old woman with history of pseudotumor 
cerebri, now admitted due to 3 episodes of LOC concerning for 
possible seizures. Neurologic examination upon admission was non 
focal. CT cervical spine ___ negative for fracture or 
dislocation. cvEEG monitoring showed left temporal spike and 
wave discharges. MRI brain w/ and w/o contrast was normal with 
no evidence of seizure focus. She was started on levetiracetam 
1000 mg BID and received the first dose in house. She will 
follow up with her outpatient neurologist. She was educated 
about seizure precautions and the importance of starting 
medication. 
 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. This patient is not taking any preadmission medications

 
Discharge Medications:
1.  LevETIRAcetam 1000 mg PO BID 
RX *levetiracetam [Keppra] 1,000 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth twice a 
day Disp #*60 Tablet Refills:*1 
2.  Lidocaine 5% Patch 1 PTCH TD QPM 
RX *lidocaine 5 % apply to shoulder daily Disp #*15 Patch 
Refills:*0 
3.  Naproxen 500 mg PO Q12H:PRN Pain - Moderate  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
LOC episodes concerning for Seizures

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You came to the hospital because you had several episodes where 
you fell out of bed and woke up on the floor, as well as another 
event when you fell over at home during the day. Although we 
cannot be sure what happened, because no one saw them, these 
kinds of episodes are concerning for seizures.

While you were here, we monitored your brain waves on EEG. We 
saw that there is electrical activity in your brain which can be 
associated with seizures. The EEG is a measure of your brain 
waves now and gives us a picture of what your brain activity is 
like normally. It does not tell us exactly what happened in the 
past. However, given the combination of your description of the 
events, and the epileptiform discharges on your EEG, we think 
that it is very likely that you had seizures at the times that 
you fell out of bed.

We recommend that you start a medication to decrease your risk 
of seizure. We would like for you to take Keppra 
(levetiracetam). This medication is a very benign medication. 
Sometimes people find that it causes them to be more irritable 
or to have more mood swings. If you are having this problem we 
recommend that you continue taking the medication and we will 
think about switching it at your follow up appointment.

We have given you a lidocaine patch for your shoulder to help 
with the pain. We recommend rest, heat or ice, an 
anti-inflammatory medication and gentle stretching to help the 
bruise heal.

In the ___, the law is that you should not 
drive for six months following any loss of consciousness. If you 
have another loss of consciousness (passing out, seizure), the 
clock will restart and you will need to wait another six months. 
In addition, we recommend not bathing or swimming alone, as 
there is a risk of drowning if a seizure occurs. Avoid hazardous 
situations should a seizure occur, such as tree climbing or 
bicycling on the street with traffic.

There are some things that can trigger seizures. This includes 
sleep deprivation, alcohol use, illness (particularly nausea and 
vomiting where you cannot tolerate your medications) or missing 
medications. 

Please talk with your neurologist if you intend to become 
pregnant to discuss the management of your seizure medications 
as well as any headache medications you may take in the future.

It was a pleasure taking care of you.

- Your ___ Team
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:

History of Present Illness:
This is a ___ M with Stage IV pancreatic adenocarcinoma 
metastatic to retroperitoneal lymph nodes and lungs, DVT on 
Lovenox, SIADH admitted from the PACU after port placement. He 
presented for elective port placement ___. Case started under 
MAC, but patient had difficulty lying flat due to cough. He had 
wheezing, stridor and needed frequent suctioning. Port placement 
was complicated and patient was intubated during procedure. He 
was difficult to extubate and required nebs. Following 
extubation, he continued to have cough, stridor, wheeze. 

Patient reports that he has had a dry cough for the past 4

Brief Hospital Course:
This is a ___ M with history of stage IV pancreatic 
adenocarcinoma with significant lung involvement/lymphangitic 
spread, DVT on Lovenox and SIADH who was admitted due to 
difficulty weaning off the ventilator following port placement. 

# Dyspnea, hypoxia and cough: Patient had cough and hypoxia to 
high ___ on room air. Recent CXR and CT scan are 
suggestive of extensive pulmonary metastases and likely 
lymphangitic spread, which are likely etiology of patient's 
cough. No fever or sputum production to suggest pneumonia, and 
CT shortly prior to admission was without evidence of pneumonia. 
There was likely also an element of atelectasis following 
anesthesia contributing to increased hypoxia. Pt does has hx of 
DVT, but is on anticoagulation with Lovenox, so PE was not 
considered likely. x2. Patient was given ipratropium, albuterol 
nebs, continued on benzonatate and incentive spirometry with 
rapid improvement in his symptoms.

# Stage IV pancreatic cancer: s/p port placement for anticipated 
start of chemotherapy next week.

# Leukocytosis: Likely stress response in setting of significant 
cancer burden and possibly aspiration during procedure. No 
fevers or evidence of pneumonia. 

# Tachycardia: Likely secondary to fluid depletion in setting of 
being NPO for surgery, and responded to IVF.  PE was in ddx as 
above, but patient has been anticoagulated. EKG showed frequent 
PVCs and non-specific ST changes. Troponins were negative.

# Hyponatremia: Likely secondary to SIADH. Na 130 at discharge.

# Hx of DVT/PE: Continued on  lovenox

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
- Recheck Na at ___ Oncology appt to ensure hyponatremia is 
stable.

at ___ did not show any growth.  On arrival to ___ his 
sedation was weaned, his lactulose dose was increased, continued 
rifaximin and hypernatremia was managed with D5W boluses.

throughout the course of this hospital stay.

for prophylaxis for variceal bleed. Last EGD ___ showed 3

with air insufflation.  Patient does not have any history of SBP

increase in the size of the hematoma.

# Hemothorax: Chest CT on ___ showed large hemothorax with 
hematoma tracking along the right chest wall. Patient required a 
total of 4 units red cells to maintain Hct > 21.  Given the 
loculation and large hematoma seen on imaging, patient was taken 
to the OR afternoon of ___ by thoracic surgery for removal of 
hematoma and placement of 3 chest tubes. He tolerated the 
procedure well without complication. Patient's heparin drip (for 
pulmonary embolism, see above) was stopped prior to going to the 
OR. Chest tubes were removed on ___ without 
complications and hematocrit remained stable. 
 
#Erythrocytosis: Pt without history of high H/H. Pt may be dry 
or physiologic compensation for hypoxia (secondary 
polycythemia). CBC trended and dropped to a low of 21.7 in the 
setting of hemothorax (see above). At discharge H/H was 
9.2/29.0. 

# Hypoxic respiratory distress: Multifactorial: Large PEs, PNA, 
pulm infarct, pleural effusion and pulm edema ___ LV 
dysfunction; improved with diuresis and thoracentesis c/b 
pneumothorax. Likely from markedly elevated filing pressures as 
well as possibly an element of compressive atelectasis due to 
the effusion. Now he is more comfortable, satting well on room 
air.

Chronic issues: 
#OA/DJD: Chronic, takes Aleve and Tylenol at home. Tylenol PRN 
for pain control in house.

#OSA: Uses CPAP at home. Patient's wife brought home CPAP in and 
overnight CPAP was continued.

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
-Consider hypercoagulability workup: for patient that is taking 
anticoagulant, consider acute thrombophilia test profile: APCR, 
fasting homocysteine (level 17.1, ___, lupus anticoagulant, 
Anticardiolipin antibodies IgG and IgM, Prothrombin ___ 
mutation assay; however, this may not be needed as patient was 
fairly immobile prior to developing PE and also likely needs 
lifelong anticoagulation and many of these tests would require 
patient to be off anticoagulation
-Needs anticoagulation for at least 3 months
-Incidental thyroid nodule found on ??, will need outpatient U/S 
to further evaluate

assist

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

It was a pleasure taking care of you during your hospitalization 
at ___. You were admitted with a new abnormal heart rhythm and 
leg swelling and were found to have clots in your lungs. You 
also had some fluid outside of your lungs which was drained. 
Some air escaped from your lung during the procedure and a chest 
tube was placed to help the lung re-expand. You had bleeding at 
the site of the chest tube which was evaluated by thoracic 
surgery. Because the amount of blood collected outside your lung 
was too large to drain, you were taken to the operating room for 
removal of this blood collection and three separate chest tubes 
were placed. You improved and the tubes were removed. You also 
underwent cardioversion for treatment of your abnormal heart 
rhythm and remained in normal rhythm following medication with 
amiodarone. Your heart failure was exacerbated by your abnormal 
rhythm and the pulmonary emboli. You were treated with diuretics 
to remove extra fluid and medications were used to maintain your 
blood pressure when it dropped too low. You were seen by 
hematology/oncology for your elevated white blood cell count and 
your studies were all normal, indicating that the high white 
blood cell count was likely a reaction to stress and or 
infection. Please attend all follow up appointments as indicated 
and take all medications as prescribed.
Weigh yourself every morning, call Dr. ___ weight goes 
up more than 3 lbs in 1 day or 5 pounsd in 3 days.

Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
abdominal pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Upper endoscopy

 
History of Present Illness:
___ yo ___ M with large cystic adenocarcinoma of 
the pancreas, inoperable due to vascular encasement s/p 
Gemcitabine last ___ presents with worsned abd pain, new cough 
and occassional dyspnea.  
.
He has been doing less well recently; his chemo cycle for this 
past week was held due to decreased counts with plan to resume 
this week. He has had a fair amount of abdominal pain, and had a 
scheduled celiac block in the near future. He comes in today 
with abdominal pain that has increased to ___. He has also been 
taking more pain medication at home recently. Per Dr. 
___ from this week, his fentanyl patch was 
increased on ___, which is 4 days ago. 
.
He has had some mild shortness of breath that is new today, no 
DOE, no orthopnea.
.
He denies any other symptoms. Specifically, no change in bowel 
habits, no bleeding, no fever, no headache, no chest pain, no 
nausea, no neurologic changes. A full review of systems was 
otherwise negative.
.
On the floor, his pain now is currently a ___, but rising.

.
Initial VS in the ED were: 98.6, 102, 105/65, 18, 100%/RA
VS on transfer 99.5, 85, 110/60, 100%/RA Neuro A&OX3 without 
deficit. Eating and drinking OK.
.
Labs significant for a Na of 126.  CBC with WBC 11.8, Hct 27.8.  
Bili, AST, ALT elevated. UA neg for UTI.
.  
CT chest/abd/pelvis: opacificiation in b/l lungs seen in ED. 
Blood cultures were sent. Abd/pelvis shows some progression of 
disease with portal vein not well visualized. 
.
Received Ceftriaxone and Azithromycin. Got 8mg IV Morphine. No 
IVF given.  
 
Past Medical History:
Mr. ___ has a history of chronic
pancreatitis and pseudocyst development.  He underwent a cyst
jejunostomy with Roux-en-Y in ___ in ___ and was 
hospitalized following this for acute on chronic pancreatitis 
with pseudocyst formation.  He was given TPN and supportive 
treatment while awaiting maturation of the pseudocyst and 
potential surgical intervention. During that admission a CT of 
the abdomen/pelvis was reported to show a 16 x 8.6 x 16cm 
multi-loculated cystic mass essentially replacing the entire 
pancreas.  He was transfered to ___ for further evaluation and 
management.  It was determined that this lesion was inoperable 
due to encasement of the blood vessels.  He underwent EUS and 
had an FNA ___, which demonstrated atypical cells, 
concerning for a mucinous neoplasm.  He underwent ERCP on 
___ which showed malignant cells consistent with 
adenocarcinoma.  Tissue biopsy has not been feasable due to the 
location/nature of the mass.
.
Other Past Medical History:  
- ___ - cholecystectomy for gallstone pancreatitis and
subsequently developed a pseudocyst.
- ___ he was reported to have undergone cyst jejunostomy with
Roux-en-Y in ___. 
- Hypertension
- Splenectomy secondary to trauma, ___

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
No known family history of pancreatic disease. No family history 
of disease he reports.

HEENT:  PERRLA. MMM. no LAD. no JVD. neck supple. 
Cards: RRR S1/S2 normal. no murmurs/gallops/rubs.
Pulm: No dullness to percussion, CTAB no crackles or wheezes 
appreciated.
Abd: Soft lower down, firm abdominal mass palpable in epigastric 
region. No apparent organomegaly. Mild tenderness in 
epigastrium; no rebound.
Skin: no rashes or bruising
Neuro/Psych: CNs II-XII intact with exception of visual field 
testing which was deferred but no gross abnormalities in vision 
appreciated. Oriented to hospital, unsure of name.   
.

VS: Tm 98.5 Tc 98.5 HR 91 (81-93) BP 100/60 (94-104/60-62) RR 18 
SaO2 99% RA
GEN: Chronically ill appearing gentleman, sitting in chair, in 
no acute distress.
HEENT:  PERRLA. MMM. no LAD. no JVD. neck supple. Thrush evident 
on tongue surface.
Cards: RRR S1/S2 normal. Crescendo systolic murmur best heard at 
___, no gallops/rubs.
Pulm: No dullness to percussion, CTAB, no crackles or wheezes 
appreciated.
Abd: Soft lower down, firm abdominal mass palpable in epigastric 
region. No apparent organomegaly. Mild tenderness in 
epigastrium; no rebound.
Skin: no rashes or bruising
Neuro/Psych: CNs II-XII intact with exception of visual field 
testing which was deferred but no gross abnormalities in vision 
appreciated. Oriented to self, hospital, month and year.
 
Pertinent Results:
___ CT C/A/P:  
1. No evidence of pulmonary embolism within limitations of 
timing bolus. 
2. Opacification in bilateral lungs, right greater than left, 
with ___ pattern is concerning for infectious etiology.  
  
3. Pneumobilia likely secondary to recent stent in common bile 
duct. 
4. Hypodensities replacing most of the pancreas consistent with 
pancreatic 
pseudocyst, appears increased in size compared to ___. Combine transverse dimension is now 18 cm, previously 16 
cm.   
5. Main portal vein not clearly visualized in the study and 
appears occluded. This was better seen on prior CT scan.   
6. Right colonic wall thickening may represent reactive 
inflammation.   
7. Stable right renal hypodensity.   
8. Two splenules rather than complete spleen noted in the 
splenic bed. 
.

.
Microbiology:

Brief Hospital Course:
___ w/ a history of chronic pancreatitis and pseudocyst now with 
a large pancreatic malignancy most consistent with a mucinous 
cystadenocarcinoma p/w worsening abdominal pain and dyspnea with 
infiltrate on CT chest.
.
#. Abdominal pain: This is likely related to his malignancy, 
pain regimen was changed 4 days prior to admission, pain poorly 
controlled at home.  Pt denied pain and nausea during his 
admission; may be likely due to the fact that he was relatively 
inactive or the recent change in his pain regimen may have been 
in effect. We attempted to have GI place a celiac nerve block, 
as planned as an outpatient on ___. However, upper GI 
endoscopy was performed without celiac block ___ to the cystic 
masses per GI. We discharged the patient home pain free on his 
outpt pain regimen, which included fentanyl patch 150mcg/hr q72 
hrs,  Dilaudid ___ PO q3hrs prn, gabapentin 300mg TID and 
Tylenol ___ TID with PPI and simethicone.
.
#. Fever: Patient with cough (per wife), dyspnea (though not 
hypoxic), mild elevation in WBC, with infiltration on CT chest.  
B/l aspect makes atypical or fungal organism more likely however 
patient has not been neutropenic. Pt cont to be febrile while on 
CAP coverage of azithromycin and ceftriaxone in the setting of 
recent hospital admissions within the last 90 days. Antibiotic 
coverage was broadened for HCAP (azithromycin, vanc and 
cefepime). Blood cultures pending, unable to send sputum 
cultures. Urine legionella negative. Patient was discharged on 
home PO regimen of cefpodoxime 100 mg BID and doxycycline 100mg 
BID for 8 days. 
.
#. Portal Vein Compression ?Occlusion: Noted on imaging; abd 
pulsatile on exam. No evidence of bleeding on imaging, hct 
stable during admission.
.
#. Hyponatremia: Pt initially appeared fluid down on exam, 
though his BUN/Cr were not appreciably elevated. FeNa consistent 
with hypovolemic hyponatremia. Resolved during his admission 
with IV hydration.
.
# Pancreatic cancer: As per pt's primary oncologist, treating 
with Gemcitabine as an outpatient without available surgical or 
XRT options at this time. We continued Compazine, Zofran and 
Creon.

Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Confused - sometimes.

Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
It was a pleasure taking care of you during your admission. You
